[18:34:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
This is why non-memory-managed languages stink.  But I guess we have to live with them.

[18:35:00.0000] <gsnedders>
memory-managed languages stink because their GC tends to have bugs too :)

[18:39:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Single source of bugs in an area where the bugs are relevant to the very operation of the component is better than bugs distributed throughout every program that aren't critical to the operation of the programs.

[18:40:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, I mostly write in PHP.  Despite the PHP developers' most strenuous efforts to introduce bugs and outright insanity into all parts of the reference language implementation, it's hard to get memory to leak past the end of a request.

[18:40:01.0000] <Philip`>
Memory-managed languages don't protect you from poor caching strategies, which is sometimes what causes painful memory usage

[18:40:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, it's an improvement.

[18:47:00.0000] <Philip`>
AryehGregor: It's better than nothing, there's just a danger that people think GC means they no longer have to worry about the lifetimes of allocated objects

[18:48:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
From experience, it seems like people don't even notice the GC once they're used to it.  It doesn't make them less able to troubleshoot memory usage.

[18:48:01.0000] <Philip`>
when really you still ought to worry and the GC just means you don't have any explicit end-of-lifetime markers in your code

[18:48:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
It means that you almost never have to worry about explicitly deallocating things, not never.

[18:48:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
I've cut memory usage using unset() in PHP before.

well how else are you going to wait for a style sheet?

[05:38:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: do we know that document.written inline scripts need to wait for sheet for Web compat?

[05:38:01.0000] <Hixie>
iirc that's what browsers did when i tested it

[05:39:00.0000] <Hixie>
but who knows

[05:39:01.0000] <hsivonen>
by inspection, it seems to me that Gecko doesn't do that

[05:39:02.0000] <annevk>
Gecko used to have synchronous style sheet loading

[05:39:03.0000] <Hixie>
making things dependent on whether they'd inserted via document.write() or not seems pretty wacky

[05:40:00.0000] <hsivonen>
my axiom is that nested event loops are wacky

[05:40:01.0000] <Hixie>
well on a side note, technically the html5 spec doesn't have any nested event loops

[05:40:02.0000] <Hixie>
but that's neither here nor there

[05:41:00.0000] <Hixie>
my point is that since we need to spin the event loop for regular <script>s, that boat has sailed

[05:41:01.0000] <hsivonen>
that doesn't help much, since we are dealing with C++ method call semantics

[05:41:02.0000] <hsivonen>
so there aren't fancy yields and continuations available

[05:41:03.0000] <Hixie>
so why make an exception for document.written ones?

[05:41:04.0000] <annevk>
I think we had the ability for some time to stop script execution when a layout DOM attribute was asked for to be able to fetch the necessary style sheets and compute something... Mostly to work with sites that were depending on the synchronous style sheet loading. I suspect things have changed though. For one Gecko no longer does the synchronous loading...

[05:42:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: because for regular scripts you don't need a nested event loop in order to be able to wait for the sheet

[05:42:01.0000] <Hixie>
without the event loop, the sheet can never load

[05:42:02.0000] <Hixie>
since the load happens on the event loop

[05:42:03.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: when you tested Gecko, did you make sure to document.write the <link rel=stylesheet> and the inline script together?

[05:42:04.0000] <Hixie>
no idea

[05:43:00.0000] <hsivonen>
if the <link rel=stylesheet> is in the network stream, you block whatever script would call document.write before you get to the document.write

[05:43:01.0000] <jgraham>
hsivonen: (you can do fancy yield and continuation in C++ if you design for it, of course)

[05:43:02.0000] <jgraham>
(I'm not suggesting that doesn't make it too high an implementation burden to require it)

[05:44:00.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: do you mean with arbitrary methods on the stack and without breaking the abstraction that the program isn't supposed to mess with its own stack as raw memory?

[05:45:00.0000] <Hixie>
you can do things with setjmp/longjmp

[05:45:01.0000] <Hixie>
but i wouldn't recommend it

[05:45:02.0000] <Hixie>
you can also simply write your code so that the continuation is a separate method

[05:46:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's not like the spinning is in an arbitrary place, it's in a well-defined place

[05:46:01.0000] <Hixie>
but in practice it doesn't matter much

[05:46:02.0000] <jgraham>
hsivonen: I am not familiar with the range of implementation approaches, I just know it is possible

[05:46:03.0000] <Hixie>
i was just saying the spec doesn't technically use nested event loops

[05:47:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: that's not much of a consolation

[05:47:01.0000] <Hixie>
i don't think anybody intended it to be a consolation :-)

[06:59:00.0000] <jgraham>
Hmm, is it generally true that the list of possibilities in the tree construction algorithm can be treated as unordered? It is at least untrue in the foreignContent case, but it seems like it would be nice if it was always true

[07:00:00.0000] <jgraham>
(apart from the "anything else" type clauses of course)

[07:06:00.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: IIRC, it's unordered

[07:07:00.0000] <jgraham>
Hmm, what am I missing about EOF handling in foreign content? It seems like it doesn't switch insertion modes but reprocesses the token

[07:07:01.0000] <jgraham>
So it will just pop everything off the stack of open elements

[07:09:00.0000] <jgraham>
hsivonen: It isn't in the case of 'A start tag whose tag name is one of: "b", "big", [...]' because that rule only applies if you don't match the rule 'A start tag, if the current node is an element in the HTML namespace.'

[07:10:00.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: oh ok.

[07:11:00.0000] <jgraham>
hsivonen: Any clues about what I am missing with the EOF thing?

[07:17:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
so what happened to binary arrays?

[07:17:01.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: I think you found a spec bug.

[07:18:00.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: before reprocessing the token, the tree builder should switch to the original mode

[07:18:01.0000] <hsivonen>
or at least that's what I have implemented

[07:19:00.0000] <jgraham>
hsivonen: For everything in that clause or just the EOF case?

[07:34:00.0000] <jgraham>
hsivonen: Filed a bug

[07:35:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[07:35:01.0000] <jgraham>

[07:36:00.0000] <jgraham>

[08:00:01.0000] <m_ali>
 p = html5lib.HTMLParser(tokenizer=HTMLSanitizer,

[08:00:02.0000] <m_ali>
                            tree=treebuilders.getTreeBuilder("dom"))

[08:00:03.0000] <m_ali>
    dom_tree = p.parseFragment(html)

[08:00:04.0000] <m_ali>
    walker = treewalkers.getTreeWalker("dom")

[08:00:05.0000] <m_ali>
    stream = walker(dom_tree)

[08:00:06.0000] <m_ali>
    s = serializer.HTMLSerializer(omit_optional_tags=False,

[08:00:07.0000] <m_ali>
                                  quote_attr_values=True)

[08:00:08.0000] <m_ali>
    output_generator = s.serialize(stream)

[08:00:09.0000] <m_ali>
    #logging.debug(''.join(output_generator))

[08:00:10.0000] <m_ali>
    return u''.join(output_generator)

[08:00:11.0000] <m_ali>
I am looking to allow the user to embed videos which are in <object> tags and the sanitization changes that to text.

[08:00:12.0000] <m_ali>

[08:07:00.0000] <m_ali>

[08:08:00.0000] <jgraham>
m_ali: YOu can allow object in the sanitizer. Restricting the allowed attribute values is harder

[08:09:00.0000] <jgraham>
There is a concept of filters for treewalkers so you might be able to use the built-in sanitizer as the first stage and then write something that implements the filter interface for your own custom sanitization

[08:09:01.0000] <jgraham>
Not really documented though so you will need to look at the code

[08:10:00.0000] <jgraham>
m_ali: (as an aside I guess using cElementTree or lxml is better than using DOM as the intermediate tree format, especially if you con't plan to manipulate the tree at all and so don't care about the API)

[08:12:00.0000] <jgraham>
(and you can do tree = html5lib.parse(input, treebulder="lxml") rather than constructing a intermediate HTMLParser object by hand)

[08:12:01.0000] <jgraham>
(I think parseFragment should work as well, if not file a bug)

[08:15:01.0000] <m_ali>

[08:18:01.0000] <mikekelly>

[08:18:02.0000] <jgraham>

[08:18:03.0000] <jgraham>

[15:52:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[15:52:01.0000] <jgraham>

[15:53:00.0000] <jgraham>

[15:53:01.0000] <jgraham>

[15:53:02.0000] <mbrubeck>

[15:54:00.0000] <mbrubeck>

[15:54:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[15:54:02.0000] <jgraham>

[16:04:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
The problem with the HTMLWG is that, unlike the WHATWG, it operates under the conceit that everyone's voice needs to be heard and it's not acceptable to just dismiss people's objections out of hand.  This inevitably leads to people raising all sorts of issues that no one else cares much about, because others are forced to deal with them.

[16:05:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It doesn't seem like the CSSWG operates this way, so I don't see why the HTMLWG should have to.

[16:05:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[16:05:02.0000] <othermaciej>
it's harder to become a CSS WG member

[16:05:03.0000] <crankharder>
is there a way to specify a wildcard URL for the CACHE directive?

[16:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[16:06:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[16:06:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[16:07:06.0000] <Hixie>

http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/association-of-controls-and-forms.html#constraint-validation "Report the problems with the constraints of at least one of the elements given in unhandled invalid controls to the user."

[10:43:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It explicitly suggests focusing the element, but that's just not enough.  There needs to be some text somehow.

[10:45:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=34945

[12:43:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: You around?  Question about Hebrew numbering.

[12:43:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, I'm here.

[12:43:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Do you know how accurate the current css3-lists description of hebrew numbering is?  It looks like it's pretty easy to describe with a simple greedy additive algorithm.

[12:44:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I commented about that some time ago, didn't I?

[12:44:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah, but I can't follow that discussion well enough to be sure.

[12:44:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
The conclusion was that it should just stop at 999,999.

[12:44:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Okay, that's fine.

[12:44:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
If you do that, then it's very simple.

[12:44:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
And the appears if and only if the number is 1k or greater?

[12:45:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
the geresh

[12:45:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, there are still a couple weird things, actually.

[12:45:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Well, plus the 15/16 exceptions.

[12:45:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'd ditch all the places where it uses a Hebrew word, like 0, 1000, 2000, etc.

[12:45:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
The current algo doesn't use a word anywhere.

[12:46:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Okay, what URL are you looking at?

[12:46:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'm looking at a WD, I think.

[12:46:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css3-lists/#algorithmic

[12:46:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
It's just "choose a value from this list for the 100k digit, 10k digit, 1k digit, add a geresh if necessary, 100 digit, 10 digit, 1 digit".

[12:47:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
This looks fine to me, yes.

[12:47:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Kk, cool.

[12:47:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
I don't know how standard it is for stuff above 1000.  I've seen that convention used, but people also sometimes just continue on without a geresh.

[12:47:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
E.g., תתר for 1000.

[12:47:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'm developing a syntax to allow authors to specify list-styles themselves.  All the non-algorithmics are trivial, and I'm trying to solve as many algorithmics as I can do simply.

[12:48:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
That gets unwieldy above about 1200, though.

[12:48:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Most of them fall into either "cjk" or "additive" camps.

[12:48:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
The Hebrew one is quite simple.  The only oddity is the 15/16 thing, I think.

[12:49:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah, but that's easy enough to do with a greedy additive algorithm.  Just specify 19/18/17/16/15 as possible tokens.

[12:49:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Then it'll take those in preference to building 15/16 the "normal" way with a 10 and a 5/6.

[12:49:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Ah, I see.

[12:49:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yeah, that should work fine.

[12:50:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Good to know.

[12:51:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Stupid ethiopic and tamil numbering systems being all complicated.

[12:52:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
does css support roman numbers?

[12:52:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I can handle tamil with an addition to my additive system, but ethiopic is impossible without creating something that might as well be general purpose.

[12:52:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
zcorpan_: CSS3 Lists describes it (under the algorithmic types).

[12:53:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
My method of defining list-styles also supports it.

[12:53:01.0000] <zcorpan_>
nice

[12:54:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I currently have an example UA stylesheet that defines every non-glyph and non-algorithmic list type.  I'll be adding the algorithmics that I can handle soon.

[12:55:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I wonder where I could find someone who knows the tamil numbering system?

[12:55:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I want to confirm something before I give up on it.

[12:55:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Random fun fact - in my syntax, it's pretty easy to describe a "one, two, three" list-style.

[12:56:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
You should support Roman numerals the way the romans actually used them most of the time, with IIII instead of IV and so on.  Then it's really trivial.

[12:57:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
(fun fact: watches with Roman numerals typically have IIII instead of IV, but IX instead of VIIII)

[12:57:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Indeed, both of those systems are trivial.

[12:58:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The subtractive roman numerals just require a handful more entries in the token list.

[12:58:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
(So that it'll take "XC" for 90 if it can, frex.)

[12:58:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
The only thing I can't do in my system is support overbars, but honestly who cares.

[12:59:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'm fine with the range just being 1-39999.

[12:59:01.0000] <zcorpan_>
/me didn't know about overbars in roman numbers

characters.

[13:00:02.0000] <TabAtkins>

[13:02:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:02:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:03:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:03:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[13:03:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:25:00.0000] <boblet>
hey all, more questions on outlining algorithm — what’s it’s raison d'être? does it assist UAs to provide direct access? is it to assist browsers in DOM reflow? something else?

[06:25:01.0000] <boblet>
I feel like I understand it without really getting it

[06:27:00.0000] <hsivonen>
boblet: the primary point is allowing browsers to provide UI for navigating directly a section or getting an overview of teh document structure

[06:27:01.0000] <hsivonen>
boblet: mainly for screen readers

[06:27:02.0000] <hsivonen>
boblet: the secondary point is styling based on outline depth

[06:28:00.0000] <hsivonen>
boblet: which depends on whether browser vendors and the CSS WG add a way of selecting on outline depth

[06:28:01.0000] <hsivonen>
if such a selector proves to be infeasible, well...

[06:41:00.0000] <boblet>
hsivonen: sorry — story time. thanks for your explanation

[06:43:00.0000] <boblet>
so for sectioning root elements like figure and blockquote, is it expected they’ll contain large chunks of content with headers, or that UAs will provide access to sectioning root outlines?

[06:44:00.0000] <boblet>

[06:49:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[10:37:00.0000] <Philip`>

[10:38:00.0000] <Philip`>

[11:42:00.0000] <boblet>
regarding the accessibility design principle, would you say that “Design features to be accessible to users with disabilities” could be accurately summarised in “accessibility by default”?

[11:43:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I would say so, but it's not entirely uncontroversial

[11:44:00.0000] <boblet>
Dashiva: nothing in a11y ever is :)

[11:44:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
boblet: Subtly different.

[11:44:02.0000] <Dashiva>
There's the "bolt-on accessibility is a sign of design failure" and "bolt-on accessibility is the way to great accessibility"

[11:45:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The former could mean doing something that *can* be accessible if authors take some effort.  The latter would avoid doing that in favor of something that is, well, accessible by default.

[11:45:01.0000] <boblet>
TabAtkins: oh? uhoh

[11:46:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Ideally we want to avoid requiring any author interaction whatsoever to acheive good accessibility.

[11:46:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That isn't quite possible, so instead we just minimize the amount of author interaction necessary.

[11:46:02.0000] <boblet>
well I sense a trend towards things being more accessible by default, eg moving attribute-based meta info into main content. but I don’t see anything so nebulous in the design principles :)

[11:46:03.0000] <boblet>
aah

[11:47:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Where possible, trick authors into writing accessible content without realizing it

[11:47:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Got it, Dashiva.  ^_^

[11:47:02.0000] <boblet>
:/

[11:48:00.0000] <boblet>
actually… Dashiva, can I quote you on that?

[11:48:01.0000] <boblet>
;)

[11:48:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Simple, widely-attested truth - the amount of accessible content decreases exponentially with the amount of effort required.

[11:48:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
(Well, maybe not exponentially - I don't have any numbers to attest that.  But super-linear at least.)

[11:49:00.0000] <boblet>
no doubt

[11:49:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Re: moving attribute-based meta info into main content, that's not primarily for accessibility, that's because hidden metadata has problems in itself

[11:50:00.0000] <Dashiva>
But accessibility-targeted hidden metadata is has even more problems

[11:50:01.0000] <Dashiva>
-is

[11:50:02.0000] <boblet>
I was referring to previously a11y-focussed metadata like whatever-it-is on table

[11:50:03.0000] <Dashiva>
Since it's not only hidden, but it's basically non-existent to users who don't need the extra accessibility

[11:52:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Also: people don't know how to write good @summary text.  And auto-generated @summary is useless - if it can be autogenerated by the producer, it can be auto-generated by the consumer equally well.

[11:52:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
And then the consumer *knows* that it's auto-generated and can treat it differently than custom-crafted text.

[11:53:00.0000] <boblet>
yeah, I completely agree with the idea

[11:53:01.0000] <boblet>
did the issue about that get resolved? I should check…

[11:56:00.0000] <boblet>
review huh

[13:35:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:36:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[13:37:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:38:00.0000] <Dashiva>
If at any point you (or a script) have selected anything, it never forgets

[13:38:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[13:39:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[13:40:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[22:00:03.0000] <jwm>

[22:01:00.0000] <jwm>

[22:01:02.0000] <jwm>

[22:02:00.0000] <Hixie>

[22:03:00.0000] <jwm>

[22:03:01.0000] <jwm>

[22:03:02.0000] <jwm>

[22:04:00.0000] <jwm>

[22:04:01.0000] <jwm>

[22:04:02.0000] <Hixie>
websockets is a very simple protocol, yes -- it has like three features: a handshake with origin protection, a client/server architecture, and framing for text

[22:05:00.0000] <Hixie>
for peer-to-peer we don't have origins, the architecture is client/client, and the framing needs to support video.

[22:05:01.0000] <Hixie>
it's like completely different.

[22:05:02.0000] <jwm>
websockets 2.0 :)

[22:05:03.0000] <Hixie>
i don't think trying to use websockets is a helpful way forward here

[22:06:00.0000] <jwm>
it's just a simple way forward

[22:06:01.0000] <jwm>

[23:28:00.0000] <boblet>
does anyone have an opinion on @aria-describedby and @aria-labelledby in regard to image fallback content (@alt text) and @longdesc?

[23:29:00.0000] <boblet>
I’m guessing that if the image performs a function @aria-labelledby is more appropriate, but otherwise @aria-describedby can be used for content that would have ended up in @alt or @longdesc…?

[23:33:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's hard to give a general guideline

[23:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
depends on the exact situation

[23:34:01.0000] <Hixie>
generally speaking if you write your markup correctly you don't need to use ARIA -- it's only really to be used when writing custom widgets that HTML doesn't support

[23:47:00.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: I’m thinking about using these ARIA features as fallback until <figure> is supported by AT, the ‘belt and suspenders’ approach

[23:48:00.0000] <boblet>
(which sadly might take a while :/)

[23:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
a figure's caption is a "labelledby", but you still need alt text

[23:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
they're separate issues

[23:49:02.0000] <boblet>
oh, just remembered img in figure must have alt text huh

[23:50:00.0000] <boblet>
thanks for the sanity check

[01:48:00.0000] <Matjas>
Is using the solidus ('/>') required when using the XHTML serialization of HTML5 (by sending the document with Content-Type: application/xhtml+xml)?

[01:48:01.0000] <Hixie>
Matjas: only if you omit the end tag

[01:48:02.0000] <Hixie>
Matjas: in xml you can do <foo></foo> or <foo/>, they mean the same

[01:48:03.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. <img></img> or <img/>

[01:48:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
hsivonen: :) I guess I had assumed ant and maven were actually preferable to however else to put together a build for java apps.. but perhaps now

[01:48:05.0000] <MikeSmith>
*not

[01:48:06.0000] <Matjas>
Hixie: Thanks.

[01:49:00.0000] <Matjas>
Hixie: So <img></img> would be valid HTML5 (in XML mode)?

[01:49:01.0000] <hsivonen>
MikeSmith: well, obviously build.py isn't so nice, either

[01:50:00.0000] <Hixie>
Matjas: well you need src="" and alt="" also, but yeah, from a syntax perspective it's correct in XML

[01:50:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Matjas: <img alt='...' src='...'></img> is valid XHTML5, yes

[01:50:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's just like XHTML1 :-)

[01:51:00.0000] <Matjas>
I knew it was syntactically equivalent, but I didn't know it was actually confirming/valid. Mind = blown. Thanks guys!

[02:00:00.0000] <Matjas>

[02:01:00.0000] <Hixie>
HTML != XHTML

[02:01:01.0000] <Hixie>
</img> is only valid in XHTML

[02:01:02.0000] <hsivonen>

[02:01:03.0000] <hsivonen>
)

[02:03:02.0000] <Hixie>

[02:04:00.0000] <Hixie>
you don't need the doctype in xhtml mode

but if you have it it has to be uppercase

[02:04:02.0000] <Hixie>
<!DOCTYPE html>

frankly though i wouldn't bother using XHTML unless you have a really good reason to :-)

[13:00:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Are spaces prohibited in href?  If so, why?  Do browsers not encode them consistently when making the request?

[13:04:00.0000] <Philip`>
AryehGregor: They're prohibited in the URL syntax, I think

[13:04:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
The validator says so.  Do you know why?

[13:04:02.0000] <Philip`>
and it's not HTML's job to redefine the valid URL syntax

[13:06:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, it looks like the browser encodes the spaces as %20.  Something must tell it to do so, unless that's unspecced.

[13:07:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Anyway, it's HTML's job to say what markup is valid.  It could provide a preprocessing algorithm and then say the URL is valid HTML if the result of the preprocessing is a valid URL.

[13:09:00.0000] <jgraham>
AryehGregor: It does

[13:09:01.0000] <jgraham>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/urls.html#valid-url

[13:10:00.0000] <jgraham>
The %20 thing comes from the "resolve an address" algorithm

[13:10:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:11:00.0000] <jgraham>

for example

[00:17:00.0000] <boblet>
hsivonen: I enjoyed your http://hsivonen.iki.fi/-webkit-html5/ article. another problem is it’s hard for authors to know what vendor prefixes to add. is there a resource listing what CSS things have vendor prefixes? if not can we set a wiki up somewhere?

[00:21:00.0000] <boblet>
hsivonen: also you might want to mention in the conclusion that for bits of the spec that are implemented the same way using vendor prefixes by more than one browser it’s good to add the non-prefixed version too, for future support.

[00:21:01.0000] <boblet>
bbl

[00:40:00.0000] <hsivonen>
boblet: adding the non-prefixed version (which I do on my site) defeats the point of prefixes, too 

[00:41:00.0000] <hsivonen>
boblet: since it creates a body of legacy content that assumes that standardized syntax works the same as the initial prefixed syntax

[00:42:00.0000] <hsivonen>
boblet: as I see it, the only real solution is to speed up the process from having two implementations to the point where the prefix is removed and the CSS WG agrees not to bikeshed the feature anymore

[00:43:00.0000] <hsivonen>
boblet: and to make that happen, vendors should be required to contribute sufficient editor time to the CSS WG when they come up with a CSS extension

[00:43:01.0000] <hsivonen>
boblet: but there's no way to enforce such a person-time contribution rule

drclue, if it's the default port of the scheme the origin production will not include the port

[13:23:01.0000] <annevk>

[16:43:00.0000] <Dashiva>
volkmar: I checked the discussion from when it was changed, and it turns out float won't work at all since the timestamp is milliseconds and not seconds

[16:47:00.0000] <Philip`>
Dashiva: Why does the scale matter? Doesn't that just mean the maximum is 10^34 seconds, not 10^37 seconds?

[16:48:00.0000] <Philip`>
(so it's still plenty of ages of the universe)

[16:49:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Philip`: Timestamps need to be precise, so a float is pretty much a 24-bit integer in this regard

[16:50:00.0000] <Dashiva>
But I suppose you're right, and float would be too small even for seconds

[16:51:00.0000] <Philip`>
Oh, so the issue is that it has a precision of milliseconds and a range of >2^24 larger than that, rather than the issue being that it's scaled to milliseconds

[16:52:00.0000] <Philip`>
Things would be much easier if time didn't change so frequently

[16:53:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Sounds like you're onto something

[16:54:00.0000] <Philip`>
24fps is enough for visually smooth animation in films, so we could just quantise the universe to ~100Hz and nobody would notice

[16:54:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'm pretty sure we'd notice when chemistry stopped working.  Well, actually, we wouldn't, but for entirely the wrong reason.

[16:57:00.0000] <Dashiva>
It seems today's date requires 31 bits for second precision, 41 for millisecond precision

[16:58:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It requires 0 seconds for arbitrary precision, if you pick the start date correctly.

[16:58:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It requires 0 bits for arbitrary precision, if you pick the start date correctly.

[16:59:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[22:06:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
the prose of the MathML specs don't ever seem to actually define the content models for many elements

[22:06:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
e.g., http://www.w3.org/TR/MathML3/chapter3.html#presm.mi

[22:20:00.0000] <Dashiva>
MikeSmith: It seems RelaxNG is the conformance basis, the prose expands on that

[22:21:00.0000] <Dashiva>
"A valid MathML expression is an XML construct determined by the MathML RelaxNG Schema together with the additional requirements given in this specification."

[22:22:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Dashiva: OK

[22:22:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Seems like an inconvenient arrangement for authors

[22:22:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah

[22:23:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
but specs really aren't for authors anyway

[22:23:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
I can see from reading back to http://www.w3.org/TR/MathML3/chapter3.html#presm.tokel that there is something of a prose definition there

[22:24:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
but that really seems like and suboptimal way to do it

[22:25:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
"With the exception of the empty mspace element, token elements can contain any sequence of zero or more Unicode characters, or mglyph or malignmark elements"

[22:26:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
but then it never even explicitly defines what "token elements" are

[22:26:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
oh wait

[22:26:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
it does in the next paragraph

[22:26:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
"Token elements represent identifiers (mi), numbers (mn), operators (mo), text (mtext), strings (ms) and spacing (mspace)."

[22:26:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
sorta

[22:27:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
though no hyperlink for "token elements" or dfn markup or anything there

[22:28:00.0000] <Dashiva>
A bit weird that mspace is a token element when it isn't allowed to contain tokens

[22:29:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah

[22:31:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
anyway, I'm just trying to figure out of having validator.nu allow HTML markup in mi and mn and mo violates MathML semantics

[22:32:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I think I'll just try having it allow HTML markup within any "token element"

[22:33:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
if hsivonen is OK with that

[22:34:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
but that means also allowing it within mtext

[22:34:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
and within the ms element

[22:34:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
whatever that is

[22:34:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
"An mtext element is used to represent arbitrary text that should be rendered as itself."

[22:35:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I guess an HTML <img> of text could be considered to "represent" text

[22:36:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
「The ms element is used to represent "string literals" in expressions meant to be interpreted by computer algebra systems or other systems containing "programming languages".」

[22:37:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
but 「Note that the string literals encoded by ms are made up of characters, mglyphs and malignmarks rather than "ASCII strings".」

[22:37:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
so I say we are OK there, too

[22:39:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
anyway, restricting it to allowing HTML phrasing content seems reasonable

[22:39:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
that is, allowing HTML phrasing content within any MathML "token element" 

[22:39:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
as far as validation goes

[22:40:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hmm, yeah, and that seems to align with the HTML5 parsing algorithm too

[05:22:00.0000] <jgraham>
/me notes that the polyglot spec is a set of inferences rather than a definition

[05:29:00.0000] <Lachy>
TimBL suggestion that the polyglot spec be made normative is misguided. It must stay entirely non-normative because it doesn't specify anything beyond what HTML5 itself specifies, it just describes the requirements in a way targetted towards authors wanting to write polyglot documents

[05:31:00.0000] <jgraham>
Lachy: I just said something similar on the list

[05:31:01.0000] <Lachy>
also, I don't see the point of it. It just duplicates much of what will go into my HTML5 Reference and HTML5 Guide. (I'm hoping I will be allocated some time to work on that soon too)

[05:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
It has the advantage of not always being in the future tense

[05:32:01.0000] <Lachy>
I don't have a problem with it being published though, I just think the work should have gone into contributing to the HTML5 Reference, rather than being separate

[05:33:00.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, yeah, that's true. It's just that I've been allocated to so much other QA tasks rather than spec work.

[05:34:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
it normatively specifies what an "XHTML/HTML polygot document" is

[05:35:00.0000] <jgraham>
MikeSmith: The only normative text needed to do that is "an XHTML/HTML polygot document is a document that conforms to all the authoring requirements of HTML and XHTML"

[05:36:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: That's not a useful definition, since you want polyglot documents to act similarly when processed as XHTML and HTML

[05:37:00.0000] <Philip`>
which means you need more restrictions, based on subjective views of what is similar enough behaviour

[05:38:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: documenting things that cannot be strictly inferred from either spec seems fine

[05:38:01.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, there's no need for there to be a normative definition of what's considered to be polyglot anyway.  There only needs to be guidelines.

[05:39:00.0000] <jgraham>
So maybe "can't be normative" is wrong

[05:39:01.0000] <jgraham>
er

[05:39:02.0000] <jgraham>
Not that I said that

[05:40:00.0000] <jgraham>
So it is OK to have the parts that can't be infered from other specs considered normative

[05:40:01.0000] <jgraham>
I wouldn't bother myself, but there we go

[05:40:02.0000] <Lachy>
Although there are certainly some things authors need to do for strict polyglot documents that can't necessarily be implied purely from the conformance requirements of either HTML or XHTML, there is no reason for those to be normatively specified.

[05:41:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: Do you think most of the HTML5 spec's syntax definition should be non-normative, because it can be inferred from the parsing definition?

[05:41:01.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: It can't

[05:41:02.0000] <Lachy>
besides, most authors aren't really interested in writing strict polyglot documents anyway. They just want to use certain talismans for what they perceive as cleaner markup.

[05:41:03.0000] <jgraham>
Strictly speaking

[05:43:00.0000] <jgraham>
(they are independent in the sense that one applies to authors and one applies to UAs. Of course there has to be some common ground to make the definitions useful, but you can't infer what the common ground is without normative author requirements)

[05:44:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: You could derive e.g. the syntax for start tags from the relevant fragment of the parser definition (avoiding cases that are parse errors), I think, so the spec doesn't need to define the syntax again in terms of all the angle brackets and spaces

[05:44:01.0000] <Philip`>
(It would just need to add a few extra requirements about not including ` in unquoted attribute values etc)

[05:46:00.0000] <Philip`>
The list of omittable tags could be omitted, and derived from examining the parser for tags that can be omitted without errors and without changing the DOM, etc

[05:48:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: Yeah, I suppose that could theoretically work. Making seperate normative author/UA requirements still feels rather different to expressing the same author requirements in multiple places

[05:48:01.0000] <jgraham>
all with the same normative status

[06:13:00.0000] <hsivonen>
I think a the polyglot doc should be a set of inferences and, therefore, non-normative

[07:03:00.0000] <Lachy>
hsivonen, what do you mean by "ignoring the CDATA section exposure domain modeling error in the DOM itself"?

[07:03:01.0000] <Lachy>
are you referring to the fact that CDATA sections are exposed through the DOM API?

[07:05:00.0000] <Lachy>
or to the fact that things like <script><![CDATA[ ... //]]></script> inherently parse differently in HTML and XHTML, but which should be ignored for polyglot checking purposes?

[07:21:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: I mean that CDATA nodes should be considered equivalent to being next nodes and then adjacent text nodes should be coalesced before comparison

[07:21:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: since the HTML parser in foreign content generated text nodes, not CDATA nodes for <![CDATA[...]]>

[14:47:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Most authors don't understand semantic markup.  If you tell them that the new standard says you can only use semantic markup, they'll just misuse it horribly.  Or, at best, translate automatically to <span style="font-family:monospace">.

[14:47:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[14:48:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[14:48:01.0000] <Hixie>

[14:48:02.0000] <Hixie>
news at 11

[14:49:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
If you aren't designing the semantics to minimize misuse by authors, what's the point?  If even the authors of really large web apps don't get it, who will?

[14:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
the problem is that authors write inaccessible pages

[14:49:02.0000] <Hixie>

[14:50:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
No, because UAs will know that <font> is not semantic.  They won't know that for <em>.

[14:50:01.0000] <Hixie>
i don't see how that's ad advantage

[14:50:02.0000] <jgraham>
The general statement of the problem is "a general purpose UA can't make use of inconsistent semantics"

[14:50:03.0000] <jgraham>
(or at least can't make optimal use)

[14:50:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
If authors are encouraged to misuse semantic elements for presentation, you get a <table> situation, where you can't infer any semantics because it's usually used for presentation.

[14:50:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
(encouraged as in they have an incentive to, not as in they're told to)

[14:51:00.0000] <jgraham>
(but allowing <tt> doesn't help much because people will still pick the wrong choice an appreciable fractio of the time)

[14:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
ok now sam is just treating me like a child

[14:51:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
If you treat <tt> the same as a parse error, that's a strong reason for authors to replace it with <code> (which is shorter and easier to type than <span style="font-family:monospace">).

[14:52:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
If the validator just says "maybe you could consider using semantic markup instead if possible", then you'll increase the signal-to-noise ration in semantic markup.

[14:53:00.0000] <Hixie>
we tried that in html4

[14:53:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
And authors didn't use semantic markup.  Okay, well, they aren't going to anyway.

[14:53:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
So nothing lost.

[14:53:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Forcing them to either mass-convert their pages to a syntax that's (at best) logically equivalent, or just give up on validation, is not a win.

[14:54:00.0000] <Hixie>

[15:18:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
You can't make things not validate based on an idealized notion of what authors should do.  Validation has to reflect reality.  If it makes unreasonable demands, authors will ignore it or evade it.  You have to look at whether a requirement will actually improve pages in practice, not whether it would improve pages if authors hypothetically followed it.

[15:18:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
In practice, by allowing <code> and <span style="font-family:monospace"> but not <tt>, you'll just encourage authors to move en masse from the latter to the former.

[15:18:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's not an unreasonable demand to make pages accessible

[15:19:00.0000] <Hixie>

[15:19:01.0000] <Hixie>

[15:29:05.0000] <Hixie>
yes!

[15:29:06.0000] <AryehGregor>
Mostly you don't *want* table layouts, is the thing.

[15:29:07.0000] <Hixie>
so is <tt>-based and <font>-based markup

[15:29:08.0000] <Hixie>
and <div>-based markup for that matter

[15:30:00.0000] <Hixie>
(i originally wanted to ban <div> too but sadly people found good use cases for it too)

[15:30:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
If that's really true, authors will move away from it by themselves.  Few have.

[15:30:02.0000] <jgraham>
<em> and <i> seem roughly equally hard

[15:31:00.0000] <jgraham>
Which seems like the problem AryehGregor is concerned with

[15:31:01.0000] <jgraham>
(I know <i> is allowed)

[15:31:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Provide them with a superior technology, one that they can clearly see is superior, and they'll use it.

[15:31:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Validators never banned tables, and they disappeared regardless, because they were a pain to use.

[15:31:04.0000] <Hixie>
i don't expect all authors to get the finest points of the phrasing element definitions (though i certainly hope that html5's much clearer definitions will increase the understanding by orders of magnitude over html4's)

[15:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Almost no authors read the spec, so definitions don't help much.

[15:32:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Even very savvy authors don't read specs.

[15:32:02.0000] <Hixie>
the definitions spread to tutorials

[15:32:03.0000] <Hixie>
furthermore, using them results in more maintainable code than inline formatting, so i think it's a win already

[15:33:00.0000] <jgraham>
AryehGregor: I think you are wrong about <table>

[15:33:01.0000] <Hixie>
i don't really think it's the end of the world if people use <code> instead of <kbd> or <samp>, at least not to the extent that it's a problem if they use <table> instead of <aside>

[15:33:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
The point is that if you tell people they can't use <tt>, they'll port everything blindly to <code>.  They won't move to semantic markup.  You're getting rid of machine-detectable non-semantic markup in favor of non-machine-detectable non-semantic markup.

[15:33:03.0000] <Hixie>
similarly it's not the end of the world if they use <article> instead of <section> or vice versa

[15:34:00.0000] <jgraham>
Also, requiring locally better solutions doesn't work because the problems that are fixed are all exterialities from the author's point of view

[15:34:01.0000] <Hixie>
the finer grained semantics provide tools that the more adventurous authors can use to their advantage

[15:34:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
jgraham, what do you mean?

[15:35:00.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: i don't think it's the end of the world if they use <code> instead of <tt> for a start. When they mature as authors they might start using <samp> where it's more appropriate, e.g. if they decide they want to style something differently (rather than using classes)

[15:35:01.0000] <jgraham>
AryehGregor: The advantage of using <code> in the correct place is typically not for the authors themselves but for some third party e.g. people using screen readers

[15:35:02.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: if i were designing the language from scratch it's quite possible i wouldn't even bother with many of the current phrasing elements, they are quite fine grained and esoteric in some cases

[15:35:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hixie, but that elides a useful distinction: <tt> for "I don't have any opinion on the semantics, I just want it monospace" vs. <code> for "I want this monospace because it's code".

[15:36:00.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: *shrug*

[15:36:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
To the extent that the semantics are useful, that's a significant difference.

[15:36:02.0000] <jgraham>
sleep++

[15:36:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Requiring authors to do this kind of porting will also add to the burden of emitting valid HTML5, which will encourage authors to just ignore validation.

[15:37:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hixie, well, okay.  Just remember, I'm pretty sure I'm the first author who actually tried to port a major, heavily-used web app to HTML5.  Consider this early feedback.

[15:37:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
(Valid HTML5, of course I mean, not just <!doctype html>)

[15:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: this is not a new problem - people have been running into this porting from HTML4 Transitional to Strict for a decade or more now

[15:38:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
They had the option of not porting to Strict.

[15:38:02.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: which everyone was _supposed_ to do years ago

[15:38:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Which the large majority of web apps and pages took.

[15:38:04.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: yeah, and look at how that went

[15:38:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
MediaWiki was explicitly XHTML 1.0 Transitional because converting to Strict would have been stupid and pointless.

[15:38:06.0000] <Hixie>
it's not stupid and pointless if done right

[15:39:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I defy you to tell me one single appreciable advantage of rewriting <table cellpadding=""> in wikitext to use some kind of CSS.

[15:40:00.0000] <Hixie>
i thought we weren't talking about wikitext

[15:40:01.0000] <Hixie>
the main advantage is reduced file size

[15:40:02.0000] <Hixie>
assuming we're talking about actual data tables

[15:41:00.0000] <Hixie>
the second advantage is that once you do all the table styling in CSS, you can get _much_ prettier data tables.

[15:41:01.0000] <Hixie>
(the third advantage doesn't apply to wikitext, presumably: when editing a table by hand, it's much easier to maintain if there's no presentational cruft on every table)

[15:42:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, okay.

[15:42:01.0000] <Hixie>
the fourth advantage is that it is less likely that people will use data tables if their tables can't have presentational markup

[15:43:00.0000] <Hixie>
(also presumably not applicable here)

[15:43:01.0000] <Hixie>
the fifth advantage is that it lets you change the padding on a media-by-media basis

[15:43:02.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. to make tables tighter on a mobile device than when printed

[15:43:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Let's put it this way: MediaWiki's interface will probably become marginally more semantic to conform to HTML5.  The real problem is that we have loads of legacy wikitext that was valid XHTML 1.0 Transitional but isn't valid HTML5.  I guess this is idiosyncratic.

[15:43:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Probably not that idiosyncratic.

[15:44:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
But you can make a GIGO argument here.

[15:44:01.0000] <Hixie>
sure, if you need to bring a legacy of bad code into the modern day, you'll have a lot of work

[15:44:02.0000] <Hixie>
that's certainly very true

[15:44:03.0000] <Hixie>
for presentational wikitext, it's work that would probably need to happen anyway to make the output more accessible

[15:45:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
An impossible amount, in this case.  There are some tens of millions of pages, at least.

[15:45:01.0000] <Hixie>
yup

[15:45:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
What changes could be made in wikitext that would make the output more accessible, given editors who are clueless about accessibility?

[15:45:03.0000] <Hixie>
make wikitext just be semantic html -- semantic html is accessible by default

[15:46:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Not if people misuse it.

[15:47:00.0000] <Hixie>
instead of http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Tutorial_(Formatting) saying how to do bold, italics, and bold-italics, have the page say how to mark up the defining instances of terms on the page, how to mark up stress emphasis, how to mark up titles of works, etc

[15:47:01.0000] <Hixie>
people who can get to grips with how to write an encyclopedia can get to grips with how to write basic semantic markup

[15:47:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's not that hard

[15:47:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
We don't control that page.  It was written by users based on what they think makes the best tutorial.

[15:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
yes, but if the markup language had been semantic, they'd think that the best tutorial would be to teach the semantics of the language

[15:48:01.0000] <Hixie>
we see that all the time

[15:49:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I really think you're ignoring a lot of evidence that most people find semantic markup too much trouble to bother with, even if they actually understand it.  A proper response is to figure out why they think that and try to fix it, not just figure they're all wrong.

[15:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
i'm open to suggestions, but "just let them write inaccessible pages" doesn't cut it

[15:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
why do people prefer to write presentational markup than semantic markup?

[15:49:03.0000] <Hixie>
how do we fix that?

[15:50:00.0000] <hober>
Have your employer de-index w3schools, that might help :/

[15:50:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
For one thing, requests from non-programmer are almost always phrased in presentational terms.

[15:50:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
non-programmers

[15:50:03.0000] <Hixie>
hober: yeah, no kidding.

[15:50:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
The specifications for a web page are normally totally presentational.

[15:50:05.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: indeed, but why? how do we fix that?

[15:50:06.0000] <AryehGregor>
Designers decide how they want it to look, then developers are asked to make it look that way.

[15:51:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Because the overwhelming majority of (perceived?) users use web browsers that ignore the semantics of the documents.

[15:51:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Normal web browsers don't distinguish between <tt> and <code>, so normal users don't care, so authors don't care.

[15:51:02.0000] <Hixie>
how do we teach to designers that a web page will be rendered on dozens of devices and could have a visual presentation, a braille presentation, a voice presentation, etc?

[15:51:03.0000] <Hixie>
with different device capabilities, etc?

[15:52:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
You can't get them to care about screen readers if they have a negligible number of blind users.

[15:52:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
You might be able to get them to care about, say, cell phones.  Maybe.

[15:52:02.0000] <Hixie>
so what, screw the blind?

[15:52:03.0000] <zcorpan_>
make dreamweaver have multiple views of the document

[15:52:04.0000] <zcorpan_>
i think they've done that now

[15:52:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
No, just acknowledge that trying to mandate things that most authors won't listen to doesn't help the blind.  Authoring requirements have to reflect reality just as much as implementer requirements.

[15:53:00.0000] <Hixie>
i strongly disagree with that later statement

[15:53:01.0000] <Hixie>
i think in the case of authoring requirements, conformance requirements have to _lead_ reality

[15:53:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Why the difference?

[15:54:00.0000] <Hixie>
because authoring requirements don't affect interop

[15:54:01.0000] <Hixie>
they affect the success with which an author can convey meaning

[15:54:02.0000] <Hixie>
whereas UA requirements are intended to result in interop

[15:54:03.0000] <Hixie>
it's a huge assymetry

[15:55:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's the same reason why UA requirements have to cover every eventuality of author input, but author requirements don't have to cover every eventuality of UA output

[15:56:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Reasonable.

[15:57:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
authors have to deal with actual UA output

[15:57:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Nevertheless, you cannot preempt cost-benefit analyses by authors.  If a business is making a website to sell a product that has effectively no blind users, then you are not going to be able to persuade them to expend nontrivial resources on making things accessible to blind people.

[15:57:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Not unless you have more power over authors than standards bodies actually do in practice.

[15:58:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
The best you can do is hope people want their pages to validate, but that power becomes weaker with every additional requirement, because stricter requirements mean fewer people bother to comply.

[15:58:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Ideally, HTML would be crafted so that it's really accessible with no effort involved beyond what it takes to get the page working right in a standard visual browser.

[15:58:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Unfortunately, that's not possible.

[15:59:00.0000] <Hixie>
that's certainly true. It's why with HTML5 we've made a significant effort to remove requirements that are pointless (e.g. "ids can't start with a number") and make the actual requirements all have good reasons (like "doing this will disenfranchise the blind")

[15:59:01.0000] <Hixie>
("that" being the thing about power becoming weaker with each requirement)

[15:59:02.0000] <Hixie>
i think with HTML5 we actually get pretty close to what you describe

[15:59:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
But the blind will be disenfranchised anyway.  If you require alt text, authors will put empty alt text or lousy alt text.

[15:59:04.0000] <Hixie>
but obviously there are limits to what we can do

[15:59:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
Unless they care about the blind to begin with.

[16:00:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Wikipedia didn't allow alt text on images until like last year, when I added the feature for basically idealistic reasons.  I don't recall ever seeing a single complaint.

[16:00:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
If authors don't get complaints from actual users, they won't fix things.

[16:01:00.0000] <Hixie>
wikipedia images almost always just repeat what is already said on the page

[16:01:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's way easier to just trivially fix all the validator errors, than to actually test in a screen reader (which is what you really need to do to get a good website for the blind).

[16:01:02.0000] <Hixie>
so it's not a big deal for wikipedia images to not have alt text in many cases

[16:02:00.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: for authors who don't care about making content accessible, the alternatives i see are them using purely presentational markup, or them using non-presentational markup that approximates their semantics by virtue of defaulting to relatively close to the presentation they want

[16:03:00.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: neither is ideal, but the second option is mildly better.

[16:03:01.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: and had the benefit that it might make them look things up. maybe.

[16:03:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Shrug.

[16:03:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
I guess we'll see what happens.

[16:03:04.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: for authors who _do_ care about making content accessible, but simply don't know that it's an option, the validator complaining about presentational markup will lead them to find out how to do it.

[16:04:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Except when all the tutorials switch to using semantic-as-presentational markup instead of actually presentational markup.

[16:04:01.0000] <Hixie>
some might

[16:04:02.0000] <Hixie>
some won't

[16:06:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'd probably be more inclined to agree with you if I weren't faced with the fact that most Wikipedia pages will never validate again once we switch to HTML5.  I'll just have to view that as GIGO, I guess.

[16:06:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Maybe add an option to not allow the newly-invalid markup.

[16:07:00.0000] <Hixie>
there's definitely a dichotomy between newly created pages and legacy pages that are going to be ported

[16:07:01.0000] <Hixie>
i wish i had a good solution to that problem

[16:07:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's one we've fought with a lot

[16:07:03.0000] <Hixie>
most of the old "downplayed errors" and the current "obsolete but conforming" stuff are related to that problem

[16:08:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
If mechanical translation were used, do you think it would be better to do <tt> -> <span style="font-family:monospace"> or <tt> -> <code>?

[16:08:01.0000] <Hixie>
we need different validator behaviour for different pages, but without running into the HTML4 Transitional problem (where everyone writes new pages that claim to be legacy pages)

[16:09:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Wikitext is really hard to parse, though, so we can't feasibly do mechanical translation of any kind on the source wikitext.

[16:09:01.0000] <Hixie>
because we don't have a good solution, i've tended to favour the needs of new pages, because there will be more new pages in the future than there are pages that will be migrated

[16:09:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
We could force everyone to switch by shutting off support for old elements/attributes, but that would break . . . everything.

[16:09:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's a headache.

[16:09:04.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: i don't think you can successfully do a mechanical translation of presentational markup to semantic markup today without an intimate knowledge of the source document's typographic conventions

[16:10:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
If you could do reliable automated translation from presentational to semantic markup, semantic markup would not be needed.

[16:14:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Aren't most wikipedia images actually <figure> form?

[16:14:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I guess your decision is reasonable, but it's a huge pain in the neck for me.

[16:14:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Dashiva, yes, but we can't use that until IE8 is dead.  Don't want to rely on JS hacks.

[16:15:00.0000] <Dashiva>
You don't have to use the element, but you can use its aria mappings

[16:15:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Interesting idea.

[16:15:02.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: i completely agree that it's a huge pain in the neck for anyone with legacy content

[16:15:03.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: i have no good solution for that sadly

[16:20:00.0000] <zcorpan_>

[18:40:00.0000] <paul_irish>
anyone know if a css spec indicates i can legally mix hex notation with rgba or not?

[18:47:00.0000] <Dashiva>
paul_irish: Mix how? In the same stylesheet, or the same value?

[18:49:00.0000] <paul_irish>
well my usecase here is a linear gradient..

[18:50:00.0000] <paul_irish>
i can't think of any spec'd things that accept multiple colors like gradients do...

[18:51:00.0000] <paul_irish>
the problem is webkit doesnt allow a mix of hex and rgba values in a linear gradient definition, and i wanted to see if a spec indicates it should.

[18:53:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I guess that would depend on the specification for the property

[18:53:01.0000] <Dashiva>
E.g. https://developer.mozilla.org/en/CSS/-moz-linear-gradient doesn't say anything about the different <color> instances having to use the same syntax, so it should work in firefox

[19:50:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
paul_irish: A <color> is a <color> is a <color>.  It doesn't matter what notation you use, even for multiple occurences in one "value" like a linear-gradient() function.

[19:50:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
They all just get passed to the color parser and turned into a 4-byte number anyway.

[19:53:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
If webkit seriously doesn't allow mixed notations in color-stops in their -webkit-gradient() notation, that's extremely odd.  It would be substantially more work to disallow it than to allow it.

[20:30:00.0000] <paul_irish>
TabAtkins: i am now having trouble reproducing the bug i found. if i can, i'll file it. thx

[11:58:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, dairy+fish is fine, only dairy+meat/poultry is a problem.  Kosher food isn't quite a subset of vegan food; although all the ingredients in vegan food are kosher, there are some restrictions on the preparation and handling of food that could be a problem even if none of the ingredients are inherently non-kosher.

[11:59:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
For instance, milk is a problem according to some if not produced under Jewish supervision.  Grape juice/wine can be a problem.  Some cooked food is a problem.

[11:59:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Something like raw fruit or vegetables should always be fine, at least if you ignore the problem of bugs.

[12:06:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[12:07:00.0000] <enderandpeter_>

[12:07:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
There's a W3C HTML5 specification and also a WHATWG one.  The latter is a superset of the former.

[12:07:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
There's no reason to believe that the WHATWG will go away anytime soon.

[12:08:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Some people here would prefer it if the HTMLWG went away instead.

[12:09:00.0000] <enderandpeter_>
The WHATWG spec is a superset of the W3C one? So there is much the WHATWG one entails that W3C one does not or will not?

[12:09:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
At the moment, not "much".  The exact differences are detailed at the very beginning of the whatwg version.

[12:10:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, the WHATWG spec is a combination of a bunch of W3C specs plus some extra minor things.

[12:10:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
The W3C split it up a lot, so the spec called "HTML5" there is a lot smaller, but other parts are in other specs.

[12:11:00.0000] <enderandpeter_>
I see, I see... Personally, I think the more heads working on conforming web design, the better off the world will be. Well, maybe I will finally sit down and read the darn thing... both I suppose.

[12:13:00.0000] <enderandpeter_>

[12:16:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Try a dictionary, in this case.

[12:16:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
"Normative" means "binding, required".  Non-normative text is explanatory, not binding.

[05:30:00.0000] <nielsle>
Is it possible to get two separate contexts ctx1 and ctx2 that refer to the same canvas? I would like to use ctx1.lineTo(x,y) and ctx2.lineTo(x,y) to draw two curves in parallel.

[05:33:00.0000] <nielsle>
I can probably hack a solution together myself, but I would like html5 to solve the problem for me :)

[05:35:00.0000] <aho>
what do you mean with "draw in parallel"?

[05:36:00.0000] <aho>
you draw stuff to the canvas... and once you're done with that and the UI is back in control... the updated drawing is shown

[05:36:01.0000] <aho>
drawing onto one context or thousands doesn't change anything

[05:37:00.0000] <aho>
/me pokes nielsle 

[05:50:00.0000] <nielsle>
I am toying with a canvas based multi user paint program. Whenever the user move the mouse I use lineTo(x,y) to draw a line. If another user draws something then the client recieves a json object and I also use lineTo to draw that. This works nicely unless the client revieves a json object while the user is in the process of drawing a stroke. I can probably solve this by creating some locks.

[05:51:00.0000] <annevk>
Reading http://www.w3.org/mid/4C1359A1.7050403⊙in I'm not really sure what to say... I did not quite agree with the removal of the Atom mapping, but going as far as objecting goes way too far.

[05:52:00.0000] <annevk>
It seems e.g. Julian is far less constrained in that regard going as far as raising an issue over something as simple as a reference.

[05:52:01.0000] <annevk>
Does that mean the progress is tilted in the advantage of people that like to bicker over every detail?

[05:54:00.0000] <aho>
nielsle, well... you just have to update your canvas if an event occurs (input, network, whatever)

[05:54:01.0000] <aho>
that's all there is to it

[05:54:02.0000] <aho>
(it's single threaded - there are no locks)

[05:55:00.0000] <annevk>
he means a lock to indicate it cannot be updated right this instant because something else is going on

[05:55:01.0000] <annevk>
nielsle, we might get dedicated path objects in the future, but not for now

[05:57:00.0000] <annevk>
pretty good read: http://bitworking.org/news/2010/06/distributed-extensibility

[05:58:00.0000] <nielsle>
annevk: Yes you are right. I was asking for a path object. (Sorry if I was unclear).

[06:00:00.0000] <annevk>
I believe the thinking is that it should have been that way from the beginning, but in the beginning everything went fast, and so we're stuck with some not too great design decisions

[06:00:01.0000] <annevk>
but we can also still paper over them in the future, and had we not it would probably have taken all much longer to get universally deployed

[06:04:00.0000] <nielsle>

[16:49:00.0000] <boblet>
Normally <li>’s content is just phrasing content. if I have an <aside> or other flow element inside an <li>, should I wrap the phrasing content in <p>?

[16:50:00.0000] <boblet>
eg <li>phrasing content</li> → <li><aside>…</aside>phrasing content</li> or <li><aside>…</aside><p>phrasing content</p></li>?

[16:55:00.0000] <daedb>
Works either way, imo

[16:59:00.0000] <boblet>
thanks daedb. yeah I know it works, but I wondered if it was more ‘correct’ to explicitly add the <p>

[16:59:01.0000] <daedb>
nah, I doubt it makes any difference

[16:59:02.0000] <gsnedders>
I like fixing bugs and then finding out other code relies upon those bugs.


2010-06-13
[17:00:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[17:02:00.0000] <othermaciej>
down to 216 unread in my public-html folder....

[17:21:00.0000] <Hixie>
boblet: it technically makes no difference -- in both cases the "phrasing content" text is a paragraph, it's just that the <p> element makes it more obvious

[17:22:00.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: thanks for the clarification

[17:22:01.0000] <Hixie>
boblet: there's a section in the spec that talks about implied paragraphs (note that this is not implied <p>s, just implied "semantic" paragraphs, like the implied sections cause by <h2> etc)

[17:22:02.0000] <boblet>
aah yeah, I think that’s what I’m half-remembering

[17:22:03.0000] <boblet>
will re-read that now

[17:23:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's not an uber-clear section

[17:23:01.0000] <Hixie>
it's hard to really explain it because of the way HTML has implied elements

[22:14:00.0000] <boblet>

[22:15:00.0000] <boblet>

[07:20:00.0000] <henrikbjorn>
is it allowed to have mutiple aside's for example in a div#sidebar ?

[08:07:00.0000] <boblet>
henrikbjorn: sure. but it might be better to put multiple <section>s in an <aside id="sidebar">…

[08:09:00.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: re: the 2005 Web Authoring Stats, I’d be interested in the data for the current web. It’s been almost 5 years, so the differences would be interesting

[08:11:00.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: Also it’d be interesting to specifically check for class names that might indicate a page made with best practices — things like clearfix, group, amp — and see if the code from that small fraction of pages is different to the norm

[08:12:00.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: finally if you really want to blue-sky it I bet www-style would love something similar for CSS

[08:14:00.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: oh, sitename as id on body (eg <body id="whatwg-org">) would be another indicator

[08:19:00.0000] <henrikbjorn>
boblet: but the content in the sidebar is blocks/widgets with fx a list of recent items an ad or a tip of some sort

[08:20:00.0000] <henrikbjorn>
would that still be valid in a aside ??

[08:20:01.0000] <henrikbjorn>
with multiple sections

[08:20:02.0000] <boblet>
henrikbjorn: <aside> can contain other sectioning elements, such as multiple <section> elements

[08:21:00.0000] <henrikbjorn>
yeah but i thought aside was for referencing stuff on the page

[08:21:01.0000] <henrikbjorn>
and theese things are not related to the content

[08:21:02.0000] <boblet>
the thing to ask yourself is whether the content in the <aside> is related to the section/article it’s in, and whether the content is not essential to the understanding of the main content

[08:22:00.0000] <boblet>
aah

[08:23:00.0000] <henrikbjorn>
hopefully what i just wrote makes sense >P

[08:23:01.0000] <boblet>
if it’s unrelated to the main content (which is presumably in <article), then in an <aside> that’s a sibling of <article> (ie an <aside> that’s related to <body>) may be the way to go

[08:24:00.0000] <henrikbjorn>
okay :)

[08:24:01.0000] <henrikbjorn>
i think i get it now

[08:24:02.0000] <henrikbjorn>
thanks a lot

[08:25:00.0000] <boblet>
<body>…<article></article><aside></aside></body> is a page-level aside (applies to the page)…

[08:25:01.0000] <boblet>
<body>…<article><aside></aside></article></body> the aside applies to the article content

[08:26:00.0000] <henrikbjorn>
ohh

[08:26:01.0000] <henrikbjorn>
ahh :D

[08:26:02.0000] <boblet>
you can see an example of a page aside in the second code sample here: http://oli.jp/2009/html5-structure4/#article-page

[08:26:03.0000] <henrikbjorn>
then a aside related to body is the way to go

[08:27:00.0000] <henrikbjorn>
all this new stuff is hard >P

[08:28:00.0000] <boblet>
at the top of that page the coding style pulldown is in an aside that’s in <article>, because it’s related to the article (not the page)

[08:28:01.0000] <boblet>
heh, it gets easier

[08:28:02.0000] <boblet>
to give a simple example, you know how in HTML 4 <address> was only for the contact info for the page right?

[08:29:00.0000] <boblet>
in HTML5 you can also use <address> in an <article>, and when you do it becomes contact info for the article only.

[08:29:01.0000] <boblet>
both elements are scoped by their context — what they apply to depends on what they’re inside

[08:30:00.0000] <boblet>
Think Russian nested dolls… in cute little angle brackets ;-)

[08:32:00.0000] <henrikbjorn>
:p

[08:32:01.0000] <henrikbjorn>
thanks againg :)

[08:34:00.0000] <boblet>
henrikbjorn: np. if you have probs or questions this is a pretty good place to ask. after that check www.html5doctor.com, www.diveintohtml5.com, or even www.oli.jp ;-)

[08:35:00.0000] <henrikbjorn>

[14:28:00.0000] <aliok_>
hello everyone

[14:29:00.0000] <gsnedders>
'ello

[14:29:01.0000] <aliok_>
I am working on HTML5 support for MyFaces2 (the open JavaServer Faces implemenatation), and I want to ask something

[14:30:00.0000] <aliok_>
I saw there is a term "boolean attribute" in HTML5 spec

[14:30:01.0000] <aliok_>
the problem is

[14:30:02.0000] <aliok_>
I mean, I want to ask if I understood correctly

[14:32:00.0000] <Hixie>
aliok_: you have to ask the question to get an answer :-)

[14:33:00.0000] <Hixie>
aliok_: there's a lot of people who just look in every few hours and answer anything they see that they can answer

[14:33:01.0000] <aliok_>
I must write draggable="true" if I need to make a component draggable, while  I must write controls="controls" to show the controls.

[14:33:02.0000] <aliok_>
I am sure these difference makes sense, but I couldn't find out.

[14:36:00.0000] <aliok_>
why don't HTML5 does not accept "true" and "false" as a value of a boolean attribute?

[14:37:00.0000] <Hixie>
historical reasons from sgml (1986)

[14:37:01.0000] <Hixie>
draggable="" isn't a boolean attribute

[14:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
we really should rename "Boolean attribute"  to something else

[14:38:01.0000] <aliok_>
:)

[14:43:00.0000] <aliok_>
yes, I've learnt that. I was very mad at Chrome when it didn't allow me to drag with draggable="draggable" :) But it was right!

[14:43:01.0000] <aliok_>
thank you, <Hixie>

[14:44:00.0000] <Hixie>
np

[14:55:00.0000] <jgraham>
"""Excessive blink rates, such as those over 3 times a second can cause epileptic seizures in some users. To address this issue the user will configure the operating system blink rate for carets or selections to one which does not induce a seizure. User agents must support this method so that authors can determine the system blink rate and adjust their canvas blink rate to match that set in the operating system. """

[23:58:00.0000] <hsivonen>
MikeSmith: the HTML5 parser in Gecko is also significantly faster than the old parser. However, the HTML parser is a tiny part of the total pageload time, so making the tiny part smaller doesn't make a big difference to the overall perf

(and there's still room for perf improvements in the tokenizer in Gecko)

[00:06:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:25:04.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: in addition to the point annevk made, a major bug I see in the Process, and a bug that is actively harming HTML5, is the way dissent is handled

[06:26:00.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: specifically, "can live with" and "weakest objections" are ways to get a race to the bottom in terms of technical excellence if non-implementors start objecting a lot

[06:28:00.0000] <karlushi>
hsivonen, here you express the issue. What process implementation, do you propose?

[06:29:00.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: that WG decisions should be technically the best that implementors agree to implement even if the decisions draws loud objections

[06:30:00.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: that is, framing decisions in terms of technical merit instead of framing them in terms of least objection

[06:33:00.0000] <karlushi>
hsivonen, hmm it doesn't seem testable either. "should", "technical merit", "agree to implement" push a bit further the issue. 

[06:33:01.0000] <karlushi>
Would it help if a controversial issue was raised to have test cases, and implemented code to finally make the balance (according to different class of products)? 

[06:33:02.0000] <karlushi>
s/was raised/when raised/

[06:34:00.0000] <jgraham>
I'm not convinced test cases help the class of problems we have had in the HTMLWG

[06:34:01.0000] <jgraham>
Except insofar as they can be used to demonstrate claims about existing behaviour

[06:35:00.0000] <karlushi>
jgraham, maybe that would be a good starting point. Taking the type of issues we had and see how practically we could solve them in a testable way. If possible. 

[06:35:01.0000] <karlushi>
test cases are half part of the story. Implemented code is  necessary too.

[06:36:00.0000] <jgraham>
For some issues (X would be better as a seperate document) it's hard to see what type of testcases you could even write

[06:36:01.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: like jgraham says, test cases only help establishing what the current state of implementation is

[06:37:00.0000] <jgraham>
(because the experiment you want to do is to have X in/out of the main document and see if the implementations are of higher quality in the long term, but you can't do that)

[06:37:01.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: basically, stuff like "remove X", "split out Y", "make a non-normative reference to Z" should not be taking a group's time

[06:37:02.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: and proposals to change technical substance should be decided on technical merit--not on who threates to complain the most

[06:38:00.0000] <karlushi>
jgraham, splitting out spec is an entire different issue which might be handled at the start and has nothing to do with technical merit that was the initial point of starting the discussion :)

[06:39:00.0000] <karlushi>
* technical merit of a feature

[06:39:01.0000] <karlushi>
* specs organization

[06:40:00.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: that could be partially solved by letting a participant make non-technical proposals (like splitting the spec) only after the participant has a track record of also contributing technically

[06:40:01.0000] <hsivonen>
(by sending in good review comments, implementing the spec, writing test cases, etc.)

[06:41:00.0000] <karlushi>
hsivonen, stackoverflow model. Good participants get more ways of participating. Getting credentials in a community. Could be interesting indeed.

[06:42:00.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: the basic problem is that working groups need to be open so that new people who contribute positively can come in

[06:42:01.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: but

[06:43:00.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: not so open that anyone can come in and start process trolling the group

[06:44:00.0000] <karlushi>
hsivonen, basically you are proposing: open read access, and progressive write access with positive contributions. Worth trying, would have to be modelled a bit to understand the possible issues. 

[06:45:00.0000] <jgraham>
karlushi: It does have technical ramifications if it makes implementing harder, or affects the accuracy of the spec (because split documents diverge, for example)

[06:45:01.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: yes. also, an important point: one should be able to suggest technical "write" things right away but shouldn't feel an entitlement of getting one's suggestions accepted right away

[06:47:00.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: in fact, a strong sense of entitlement is part of the problem

[06:47:01.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: when I got involved, I didn't get paid to work on a browser

[06:48:00.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: I made suggestions, but I didn't have a grandiose feeling of entitlement

[06:48:01.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: that is, I didn't think the WHATWG were required to do things my way

[06:50:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
/me has the same experience as hsivonen

[06:51:00.0000] <karlushi>
hsivonen, yep difficult issue. Even in free community (not paid and nothing to pay), I have seen people asking for things like if we were forced to do it. (example validators when the source code was available.)

[06:51:01.0000] <karlushi>
But I'm not sure this issue can be solved.

[06:52:00.0000] <karlushi>
I guess it is the "moral" stance of each individuals which drives them. Some people are respectful. Some less. :/ very hard issue.

[11:08:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:04:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Hixie: Is there anything in particular preventing the WHATWG from adopting a similar patent policy to the W3C?

[13:12:00.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: it's definitely possible, but since there is no real concept of joining the WHATWG (you just subscribe to the list), so you couldn't require people or organizations to agree to it to join

[13:13:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think it would be good for WHATWG to have a patent policy

[13:13:01.0000] <karlushi>
TabAtkins, you need a backup [money] when shit hits the fan. It can be super costly. 

[13:15:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
othermaciej, you could require the employers of Steering Committee members to agree to it.  And ask other parties nicely if they'd like to, I guess.

[13:17:00.0000] <othermaciej>
AryehGregor: that's certainly one option - though that would be a smaller set of IPR commitments than the HTML WG has

[13:17:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yes, I think considerably smaller.

[13:17:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Adobe and Microsoft come to mind.

[13:17:03.0000] <othermaciej>
IBM also has a large patent portfolio

[13:17:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Right.

[13:18:00.0000] <othermaciej>
besides large corporation patent portfolios, there is also the theoretical vulnerability of a patent troll deliberately proposing a feature on which they have a submarine patent

[13:19:00.0000] <othermaciej>
but the W3C process is vulnerable to that too, if the patent troll simply fails to join the WG

[13:19:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
That could happen just as well in the HTMLWG.  Right.

[13:19:02.0000] <othermaciej>
so the main advantage is getting patent commitments from some of the relevant industry players

[13:19:03.0000] <Lachy>
getting all the lawyers and management from so many companies to agree to a whatwg patent policy would be a nightmare to deal with. Unfortunately, it wouldn't be as simple as just reusing the W3C patent policy either

[13:30:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I suspect you could get the three copyright holders plus google to agree, but someone would have to do the work

[13:30:01.0000] <othermaciej>
unfortunately, you probably have to be a lawyer to do anything useful on that front

[13:31:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:31:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:32:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:33:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[13:35:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:35:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:37:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[14:38:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
My hobby: annoying my wife with strange unicode smilies.

[14:41:00.0000] <othermaciej>
AryehGregor: the W3C Patent Policy is a little convoluted, but here is basically how it works:

[14:42:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(1) For any First Public Working Draft or Last Call Working Draft, there is a call for exclusion, which is an opportunity for WG Members to list specific patents or patent claims for which they will *not* agree to grant royalty-free licenses. Anything not excluded is assumed to be licensed.

[14:43:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(2) Technically, the license does not actually go into effect until the spec hits REC, but you do have to license anything you didn't exclude by LC. That's part of why specs have to go back to Working Draft if they have substantial changes made in CR - those changes could possibly entrain new IP.

[14:43:01.0000] <othermaciej>
(3) You can put certain limits on the RF license, such as basing it on the other party cross-licensing any essential claims they have on the spec.

[14:44:00.0000] <othermaciej>
You can read the whole thing if you want the gory details.

[14:44:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
So if someone actually wanted to sue someone over HTML5, they could do so anyway until 2022 or whatever.

[14:44:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
By which point most possible patents will probably be expired anyway.

[14:45:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
(since HTML5 qualifies as prior art for any essential claims, I'd think)
