[20:25:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: your description of which <a> elements on reddit are buttons vs. links makes me doubt my sanity

[20:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: it's just a matter of what they look like

[20:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>
really?

[20:34:02.0000] <othermaciej>
are the semantics of all controls defined by their appearance rather than behavior, or only links and buttons?

[20:35:00.0000] <Hixie>
i don't understand the question

[20:35:01.0000] <Hixie>
the point of ATs is to expose what the controls look like to non-AT users

[20:35:02.0000] <othermaciej>
all right, let me give a concrete example

[20:35:03.0000] <othermaciej>
look at this control:

[20:35:04.0000] <othermaciej>
http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?%3C!DOCTYPE%20html%3E%0A%3Cstyle%3E%0A%23mystery%20%7B%0A%20%20%20%20background%3A%20white%20url(http%3A%2F%2Fwww.reddit.com%2Fstatic%2Fgradient-button.png)%20repeat-x%20scroll%200%25%2050%25%3B%0A%20%20%20%20border%3A%201px%20solid%20%23C4DBF1%3B%0A%20%20%20%20display%3A%20block%3B%0A%20%20%20%20font-size%3A%20150%25%3B%0A%20%20%20%20font-weight%3A%20bold%3B%0A%20%20%20%20height%3A%2029px%3B%0A%20%20%2

[20:35:05.0000] <othermaciej>
tter-spacing%3A%20-1px%3B%0A%20%20%20%20line-height%3A%2029px%3B%0A%20%20%20%20position%3A%20relative%3B%0A%20%20%20%20text-align%3A%20center%3B%0A%20%20%20%20margin%3A%090px%3B%0A%20%20%20%20padding%3A%200px%3B%0A%7D%0A%3C%2Fstyle%3E%0A%0A%3Cinput%20id%3Dmystery%20type%3Dtext%20value%3Dmystery%3E%0A

[20:35:06.0000] <othermaciej>
I guess I should shorten that, hold on a sec

[20:35:07.0000] <Hixie>
and the point of ARIA is to enable that to happen when the browser can't figure it out

[20:35:08.0000] <othermaciej>
http://bit.ly/cK5Cfo

[20:35:09.0000] <Hixie>
you can use hte "save" link

[20:36:00.0000] <Hixie>
to get a shorter URL

[20:36:01.0000] <othermaciej>
what are the semantics of that control?

[20:36:02.0000] <othermaciej>
is that control semantically a button?

[20:36:03.0000] <Hixie>
i don't know what you mean by "semantic" in this context

[20:37:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I am refering to whatever you meant when you wrote "Authors must not use elements, attributes, or attribute values for purposes other than their appropriate intended semantic purpose."

[20:37:01.0000] <Hixie>
the intended semantic purpose of <input type=text> is a text control

[20:37:02.0000] <Hixie>
is that the purpose to which you are putting it here?

[20:37:03.0000] <othermaciej>
am I correctly using it for the intended semantic purpose?

[20:38:00.0000] <othermaciej>
or am I abusing it for the semantic purpose of a button?

[20:38:01.0000] <Hixie>
you are using it to try to prove a point in an argument, so no, it's no the appropriate intended semantic purpose

[20:38:02.0000] <Hixie>
:-P

[20:38:03.0000] <othermaciej>
you seemed to argue that a link with that styling has the semantics of a button, even if it has the behavior of a link

[20:38:04.0000] <othermaciej>
whereas something that looks like a link but has the behavior of a button is a link

[20:38:05.0000] <othermaciej>
I am wondering how far that extends

[20:39:00.0000] <othermaciej>
my understanding of control semantics is that it's tied to the behavior, not the appearance

[20:39:01.0000] <Hixie>
not sure what you mean by "behaviour of a link" vs "behaviour of a button"

[20:39:02.0000] <othermaciej>
and I was mighty confused to see you argue otherwise

[20:39:03.0000] <othermaciej>
are you saying the only semantic difference between links and buttons is their visual appearance?

[20:39:04.0000] <Hixie>
isn't it?

[20:40:00.0000] <othermaciej>
my understanding is that the semantics of a link are that it links to something

[20:40:01.0000] <othermaciej>
and the semantics of a button are that it actuates a command

[20:40:02.0000] <othermaciej>
regardless of what either looks like

[20:40:03.0000] <othermaciej>
and that properly using an <a> element for a link has consequences such as appropriate cursor and status bar behavior on hover, being recognized as indexable by search engines, etc

[20:41:00.0000] <Hixie>
isn't "link to something" a command?

[20:41:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it's a specific subset of commands

[20:41:02.0000] <othermaciej>
there are clearly commands that are not a "link to something"

[20:41:03.0000] <othermaciej>
(such as the command performed by the reddit submit button)

[20:42:00.0000] <othermaciej>
er, the reddit share button

[20:42:01.0000] <othermaciej>
similarly, "toggle" is a form of command, but that doesn't mean buttons and checkboxes are interchangeable other than appearance

[20:42:02.0000] <Hixie>
i think i could convincingly argue this about 5 different ways if i tried

[20:42:03.0000] <Hixie>
i don't think any of them would help us in the context of ATs and ARIA

[20:43:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm just trying to understand what it means to forbid using a link as a button

[20:44:00.0000] <othermaciej>
your argument seems to be based on the premise that doing that should be disallowed, but your examples of what does or does not constitute using a link as a button did not help my comprehension

[20:45:00.0000] <Hixie>
ok forget what i said about reddit. here's a better way to think about it based on what you said earlier.

[20:45:01.0000] <othermaciej>
and made me doubt my understanding of the requirement, ""Authors must not use elements, attributes, or attribute values for purposes other than their appropriate intended semantic purpose.""

[20:45:02.0000] <Hixie>
a link is something that provides the user with a URL

[20:45:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I would agree with that definition

[20:45:04.0000] <othermaciej>
(by that definition, "Submit a link" on reddit would be a link, but "share" would not)

[20:45:05.0000] <Hixie>
a button is something that provides the user with the option to activate something defined by the author at a user-selected time

[20:46:00.0000] <othermaciej>
and by that definition, "share" would be a button but you could also argue that all links (at least in the control sense) are also buttons

[20:46:01.0000] <Hixie>
so on reddit, the arrows and "share" should be buttons, and "submit a link" should be a link

[20:46:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I agree

[20:47:00.0000] <Hixie>
so using <a> for "share" is wrong

[20:47:01.0000] <othermaciej>
also agree

[20:47:02.0000] <Hixie>
ok

[20:48:00.0000] <othermaciej>
so looking at the specific example of "share", I think the point Steve and Sam were calling attention to was:

[20:49:00.0000] <othermaciej>
-> the spec makes it a validator error to put rule="button" on that <a> element, because it would be making an <a> element act as a button, contrary to its semantics

[20:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
the spec makes using <a> a validator error too, albeit one that few validators will ever be able to report in the coming few years

[20:49:02.0000] <othermaciej>
-> the spec does not make it a validator error to use href="#" onclick="..." on that <a> element, even though almost the sole use of that markup is to make an <a> element act like a button

[20:50:00.0000] <Hixie>
my point is that it does

[20:50:01.0000] <othermaciej>
(and similarly for href="javascript:...", although that's not used in this particular case)

[20:50:02.0000] <Hixie>
the spec does disallow that

[20:50:03.0000] <othermaciej>
it disallows the concept with a non-machine-checkable requirement, but does not make the syntax an error

[20:50:04.0000] <othermaciej>
however, it does make the syntax <a role="button"> an error

[20:50:05.0000] <Hixie>
right, role="" is a godsend here

[20:50:06.0000] <othermaciej>
with a machine-checkable rule

[20:51:00.0000] <Hixie>
it finally allows us an opportunity to catch this using a syntax error

[20:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
there are lots of things that cannot be caught using syntax errors

[20:51:02.0000] <Hixie>
they are no less errors

[20:51:03.0000] <karlcow>
othermaciej: the issue is in part what is the link. Is it a POST or a GET. http://bitworking.org/news/I_m_sorry__I_can_t_kiss_it_and_make_it_better_

[20:51:04.0000] <othermaciej>
in principle, a link with href="#" onclick="..." or href="javascript:..." could be a syntax error, unless that syntax serves a valid use case that cannot be achieved in any other way

[20:51:05.0000] <Hixie>
and when we can catch them we try to do so

[20:51:06.0000] <Hixie>
indeed

[20:52:00.0000] <Hixie>
(unfortunately, there are such use cases)

[20:52:01.0000] <othermaciej>
ok, so explaining what those are would help resolve the apparent contradiction

[20:52:02.0000] <Hixie>
the use cases?

[20:52:03.0000] <othermaciej>
since a naiive observer such as myself reading the change proposal might be unaware of those use cases

[20:52:04.0000] <Hixie>
href="javascript:"'s use case is exposing bookmarklets

[20:53:00.0000] <karlcow>
http://natbat.net/2009/Jun/10/styling-buttons-as-links/

[20:53:01.0000] <othermaciej>
good point

[20:53:02.0000] <othermaciej>
(my suggestion would be to cite these in your Change Proposal and/or in resolving SteveF's bugs when you get around to that)

[20:53:03.0000] <Hixie>
onclick="..."'s use case is for such things as click-tracking or general user interaction, or making links that are both functional in "AJAX" and static scenarios

[20:54:00.0000] <Hixie>
i don't understand why they are relevant to the change proposal

[20:54:01.0000] <othermaciej>
right, but you would never use href="#" [sic] for a click-tracked link that is supposed to work in both static and AJAX scenarios

[20:54:02.0000] <karlcow>
http://jontangerine.com/silo/html/button/

[20:54:03.0000] <Hixie>
making href="#" non-conforming might make sense

[20:55:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's kind of a weirdly specific case to disallow

[20:55:01.0000] <Hixie>
i mean i don't see much point linking to the same page, but why would we disallow it?

[20:55:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's just a relative URL...

[20:55:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I think Steve's point was that href="#" onclick="..." is exclusively used to make <a> elements act like buttons and has no valid use case

[20:56:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I agree that it would be an awfully specific thing to disallow, though one could claim the same of <a role="button">

[20:56:01.0000] <othermaciej>
anyway

[20:56:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I think those were the questions being asked

[20:56:03.0000] <othermaciej>
feel free to respond as you see fit

[20:56:04.0000] <othermaciej>
I should be going

[20:56:05.0000] <Hixie>
role="button" isn't specifically disallowed

[20:56:06.0000] <Hixie>
it's just not included in the list of things that are allowed

[20:57:00.0000] <othermaciej>
rather, it's not specifically allowed

[20:57:01.0000] <othermaciej>
anyway

[20:57:02.0000] <Hixie>
that's the opposite argument :-)

[20:57:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't want to argue the point further, you have explained these matters enough that I feel I understand them, but you may want to explain the above points on the list for the benefit of others

[20:58:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I hope that my confusion was understandable and I expect others may share it

[20:58:01.0000] <othermaciej>
thanks for the explanation

[20:58:02.0000] <Hixie>
the only others i care about here are sam and paul, frankly

[20:59:00.0000] <Hixie>
and last time i included counter-arguments in a change proposal i was told it was a waste of time

[20:59:01.0000] <Hixie>
and indeed it had no effect

[20:59:02.0000] <Hixie>
so i'm at a loss as to how to include this in a useful manner

[21:00:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[21:00:01.0000] <othermaciej>
explaining to Steve is useful because if he chooses to withdraw his proposal or agrees to some compromise (e.g. disallowing href="#" onclick="..." and/or explaining in more detail that buttons shouldn't be abused as links and explaining the valid use cases for <a href="javascript:">), that ends the process without Sam or Paul's opinion being relevant

[21:34:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
strawman attempt at a concise definition of what the term "the Web platform" means:

[21:34:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
[[

[21:34:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
  "a client-side (browser-side) runtime/processing environment for

[21:34:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
  Web applications and Web documents that are built using HTML,

[21:34:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
  CSS, Javascript and a couple of other core-standard formats, and

[21:34:05.0000] <MikeSmith>
  that are addressed and transmitted using HTTP, URIs and a couple

[21:34:06.0000] <MikeSmith>
  of other core-standard protocols"

[21:34:07.0000] <MikeSmith>
]]

[21:34:08.0000] <MikeSmith>
comments, suggestions, refinements, please

[15:04:00.0000] <bros>
I would like to discuss the handshaking process of the WebSockets API. Is it open for discussion?

[15:05:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
a11y people seem to focus on making features that authors could possibly use correctly if they really tried, rather than making ones that typical authors are likely to use correctly in practice without trying hard (or at all).

[15:05:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
bros, speak and you'll be heard.

[15:05:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Various people here are qualified to comment.

[15:05:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: ?_?

[15:05:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes, that statement is completely correct.

[15:05:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
To be fair, it's probably impossible to design a system where authors design accessible pages without trying.

[15:07:00.0000] <bros>
I think trying to formulate an argument solved my own problem. I was trying to make my own very mini "WebSocket server" in C when I realized I would have implement, or copy an already exisiting implementation of the MD5 hashing function. I thought this was crazy just to handshake but now I realized WebSocket servers are going to be implementing functionality such as caching, etc. which would use MD5 checksums.

[15:08:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
you could design a system where authors design pages that are accessible as a result of the author trying to achieve something else (seo, validation, or zeldman semantic kool-aid)

[15:09:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Only to a limited degree, in practice.

[15:09:01.0000] <zcorpan_>
yeah

[15:09:02.0000] <bros>
Is the WebSocket client-server handshaking process thought of as acceptable? 2 keys needing to be decoded/converted to integers/divided then a separate key needed to be concatenated with the other 2 back in string form, then hashed?

[15:09:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
I haven't seen an effective solution to get typical authors to write decent alt text.

[15:09:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Would it be in the spec if no one thought it was acceptable?

[15:09:05.0000] <bros>
No.

[15:09:06.0000] <bros>
What is the purpose of it?

[15:10:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'm not a WebSocket expert, but my impression is it's meant to prevent various types of security problems.

[15:10:01.0000] <jgraham>
bros: It is designed to prevent cross-protocol attacks

[15:10:02.0000] <jgraham>
using web sockets to spoof non-web-socket protocols

[15:11:00.0000] <jgraham>
which would be bad if the servers talking those protocols weren't expecting random web pages to connect

[15:12:00.0000] <jgraham>
(which they aren't, in general)

[15:12:01.0000] <bros>
It is there so current HTTP servers will not have to be re-written, and only servers that want to handle WebSockets need to implement it?

[15:13:00.0000] <jgraham>
Hixie: why does drawFocusRing take a canDrawCustom argument rather than a function that would be called to draw a custom focus ring if needed?

[15:14:00.0000] <jgraham>
bros: That is a seperate issue really

[15:14:01.0000] <zcorpan_>
bros: i think http://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/hybi/current/msg01198.html identified some security problems with the old protocol

[15:15:00.0000] <jgraham>
The fact that you can implement WebSockets on top of existing HTTP servers is considered an advantage though

[16:18:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Nope, regular domain names only.

[16:18:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
<ldh-str> ::= <let-dig-hyp> | <let-dig-hyp> <ldh-str>

[16:18:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
<let-dig-hyp> ::= <let-dig> | "-"

[16:18:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
<let-dig> ::= <letter> | <digit>

[16:18:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
<letter> ::= any one of the 52 alphabetic characters A through Z in

[16:18:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
upper case and a through z in lower case

[16:18:06.0000] <AryehGregor>
<digit> ::= any one of the ten digits 0 through 9

[16:18:07.0000] <AryehGregor>
Safari is allowed to accept IDNs, but it has to convert them to punycode.

[16:18:08.0000] <AryehGregor>
No one seems to do this yet, although the spec suggests it.

[16:19:00.0000] <boblet>

2010-06-17
[17:01:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
zcorpan_: so the problems with putting HTML content within annotation-xml is that the user would similarly need to wrap it in something, right? e.g, a <div>

[17:02:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
zcorpan_: I think I'm starting to agree that dealing with processing of content in annotation-xml might not be worth the trouble..

[17:02:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
What's the point of <annotation-xml>?  I feel like I've missed something.

[17:03:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I guess it's for annotating non-presentational "content" MathML

[17:03:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
So you use it inside of MathML to represent an annotation?

[17:04:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah

[17:04:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
So it's somewhat similar to SVG's <foreignContent> or whatever?

[17:04:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah

[17:04:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
sorta

[17:05:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
http://www.w3.org/TR/MathML2/chapter4.html#contm.annotation-xml

[17:05:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
but currently different in one really significant way as far as inclusion in HTML5 goes

[17:05:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
which is that HTML content in  <foreignContent>  will get processed as expected

[17:05:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
but HTML content in <annotation-xml> will now

[17:05:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
*not

[17:06:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
which I raised a bug for : http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9887

[17:06:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Oh.  I would naively think it should just be treated the same.

[17:07:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah, I think that's what others are likely to expect too

[17:07:01.0000] <zcorpan_>
MikeSmith: from spec example, the content-mathml would go directly in <semantics>, while presentational-mathml would go in <annotation-xml>

[17:07:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
zcorpan_: yeah, that's how I understand it too

[17:07:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
(though probably I didn't say that clearly)

[17:07:04.0000] <zcorpan_>
which makes me wonder why the css profile spec makes it display:none

[17:08:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[17:08:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[17:08:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[17:11:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

ah yeah

[20:53:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[20:53:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[20:53:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[20:53:03.0000] <MikeSmith>

[20:53:04.0000] <MikeSmith>

[20:54:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[20:55:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
default UA stylesheet

[20:55:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[20:55:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[21:13:00.0000] <boblet>

[21:13:01.0000] <boblet>

[21:19:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
after reading more, I find the whole <semantics><annotation-xml> markup in MathML to be seriously overloaded

[21:20:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
annotations can either be "content" annotations (=non-presentational) or presentational annotations

[21:20:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
and it is not clear at all from the spec under what circumstances (if any) there are meant to be presented to the user by default

[21:21:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
and it is not clear at all from the spec under what circumstances (if any) there are meant to be presented to the user by default."

[21:22:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
oops

[21:22:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
"A particularly important case is the use of a presentation MathML expression to indicate a preferred rendering for a content MathML expression."

[21:22:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
"Note that when a presentation MathML annotation is present in a semantics element, it may be used as the default rendering of the semantics element, instead of the default rendering of the first child."

[21:23:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
..."may be used as the default rendering"

[01:27:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: would it be possible to have the parsing algorithm just read the contents of annotation-xml elements into the DOM but do any processing on them at all?

[01:27:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
that is, even if those contents are SVG

[01:27:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
or even if the contents are MathML

[01:28:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
*into the DOM but _not_ do any processing on them at all

[01:29:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
for one thing, those contents are, after all, annotations that are not intended to be rendered in the main text flow

[01:30:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
both Gecko and Presto have default UA stylesheets with "annotation-xml { display: none }"

[01:31:00.0000] <othermaciej>
what is annotation-xml?

[01:31:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
and the MathML spec says: "The default rendering of a semantics element is the default rendering of its first child"

[01:31:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
where the first child is <mn> or whatever

[01:32:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
and the second or subsequent children are annotation-xml elements

[01:32:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
othermaciej: it's a mechanism in MathML for providing an "alternate representation" of MathML content

[01:33:00.0000] <Hixie>
MikeSmith: "processing"?

[01:33:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
http://www.w3.org/TR/MathML3/chapter5.html#mixing.alternate.representations

[01:33:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: not render it as whatever it would otherwise render it as

[01:33:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
even if it's SVG, don't render it as such

[01:33:04.0000] <Hixie>
aren't they display:none?

[01:33:05.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah

[01:33:06.0000] <Hixie>
by default?

[01:33:07.0000] <MikeSmith>
by default

[01:33:08.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah

[01:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
so...?

[01:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: does MathML call for it to be display: none, or is that convergent evolution among Gecko and Presto?

[01:34:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
so, that's overrideable

[01:34:03.0000] <Hixie>
isn't that enough?

[01:34:04.0000] <othermaciej>
if annotation-xml is itself display: none, nothing inside it will render by default

[01:35:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: ewhat if a site stylesheet sets it to actually display?

[01:36:00.0000] <Hixie>
then we'd want it to display, no?

[01:36:01.0000] <Hixie>
why else would it be set to display?

[01:38:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
OK, the problem currently is that the parsing algorithm doesn't allow you to put HTML content into <annotation-xml> elements

[01:38:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
but I think users will expect to be able to put HTML content there

[01:39:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
just as they can put SVG and MathML

[01:39:01.0000] <Hixie>
not sure how to allow it without hard-coding a list of elements

[01:39:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah

[01:40:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
it could be allowed by allowing it

[01:41:00.0000] <Hixie>
annotation-xml didn't seem important enough to hard-code a lot of elements there

[01:41:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
and instead treating SVG and MathML elements in <annotation-xml> as arbitrary unknown elements

[01:41:02.0000] <Hixie>
it'd be a lot of complexity in every parser for a very obscure case

[01:41:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: I fully agree it's not important

[01:42:00.0000] <Hixie>
i supported svg since that seemed useful and easy to support

[01:42:01.0000] <Hixie>
some mathml examples do it

[01:42:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah, I know the examples do

[01:43:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
but I don't know if there are any real-world use cases for it in Web content

[01:43:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
other than those examples

[02:10:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: another (hopefully easy to answer question) -

[02:10:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
the MathML spec current says this: "The draft HTML5 Recommendation, [HTML5], contains details for how MathML is included in HTML5 (and XHTML5)."

[02:11:00.0000] <Hixie>
not fully true yet but it will be

[02:11:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
well, I think it could be refined

[02:12:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
to say this:

[02:12:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
> >   The draft HTML5 Recommendation, [HTML5], contains details for

[02:12:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
> >   how MathML is included in HTML5 (and XHTML5), and, in turn,

[02:12:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
> >   details on where HTML content is allowed to be included in

[02:12:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
> >   MathML content within HTML documents.

[02:12:05.0000] <MikeSmith>
to make it more clear that doesn't just say how MathML can be included in HTML5

[05:01:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: distinguishing between U.S., French and other versions of Netscape back when the U.S. and France had worse crypto regulations than they have today

[05:02:00.0000] <hsivonen>
U is U.S. ("strong" crypto), N is France (no crypto) and I is international (weak crypto)

[14:45:00.0000] <zcorpan_>

[15:25:03.0000] <jgraham>

[15:26:00.0000] <jgraham>

[15:26:01.0000] <jgraham>

[15:26:02.0000] <jgraham>

[07:51:00.0000] <jgraham>

[07:52:00.0000] <jgraham>

[07:54:00.0000] <hsivonen>
/me observes that when document.write() implies a call to document.open() in Gecko, the call is always to the built-in open() and not to whatever the page has replaced open() with

[07:54:01.0000] <karlushi>

[07:55:00.0000] <hsivonen>
karlushi: so what's the use case of reading a spec you know is an already-obsolete draft when you know you could read the latest draft?

[07:56:00.0000] <jgraham>
That is, if you have stable versions, N, N+1, etc. and unstable drafts at all times t, it only makes sense to promote version N if, on averge, version N is closer to version N+1 than unstable version at time t(N)<t<t(N+1)

[07:56:01.0000] <karlushi>
hsivonen, will there be at a point a stable version?

[07:57:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[07:57:01.0000] <karlushi>
hsivonen, for you and implementers, not useful indeed.

[07:58:00.0000] <Lachy>

[07:59:00.0000] <jgraham>
karlushi: It is possible to be unstable, but to be convering on a stable point

[07:59:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: that's a reasonable use case

[07:59:02.0000] <karlushi>

easiest solution is to just say src="5496.ogv" instead of saying file://... etc.

and just make sure they're in the same directory

[11:13:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
 HTMLWG was never created.

[11:18:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[11:19:00.0000] <karlcow>
AryehGregor: at a few occasions the W3C had workshop on the future of the Web (including html). Members decided to go towards XML. They had invested time and money into it. There is the 2004 workshop, but there is also the one before this. Anyway following the Process a majority of people agreed to continue going to the XML road. 

[11:19:01.0000] <karlcow>
Only a handful of members wanted to reopen the work on html. Logically this is the road which has been followed. (not judging about the pertinence specifically at that time). I would count myself at that time in the XHTML camp for many reasons. Put let's put that aside.

[11:19:02.0000] <karlcow>

[11:19:03.0000] <karlcow>
it seems a natural and easy decision to make now. It was not in the past.

[13:12:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
When defining classes in Python, do you really have to define a class before it can be used, even if it's defined later in the file?

[13:19:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, could you de-tablefy something like this?  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Protected_Areas_of_Colorado

[13:19:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Also, yes, of course you do.  In what language is that *not* the case?

[13:19:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Same with functions.

[13:23:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: You dont' need to in Lisp.  The object system is designed such that it will throw warning for unimplemented things, but then slot in the proper class references when you define them later.

[13:24:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: That looks like it should be a table too.

[13:24:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I don't get how that would work in a typical object-oriented language.  You might have a constructor, for instance, so how could you process $foo = new MyClass(); without knowing the definition for MyClass()?

[13:24:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Lisp is partly functional, and functional languages are weird like this.

[13:24:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
If you try to *use* the class before it is defined, sure, it's a problem.

[13:24:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
What are you trying to do?

[13:25:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I have a big batch of classes in a file.  I want to organize them in a particular logical order such that the more important classes are near the top, and the little helper classes are at the bottom.  But I can't do that, because the little classes are used by the important classes, and thus must come before them.

[13:26:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Maybe it deliberately requires that earlier classes not use later classes, to avoid infinite loops?

[13:27:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's just as silly.  It's perfectly fine to have classes hold references to each other (other than the GC problems such causes).

[13:27:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Do other totally-non-functional languages permit this kind of thing?

[13:28:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I have no idea.  Lisp's object system *is* generally more advanced than most other languages'.

[13:28:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me discovers that he's supposed to spend like two hours going down to Courant and back to fill out some form . . . yay.

[13:28:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Got to go, I guess.

[13:28:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
kk

[13:31:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Anyway, Lisp's object system is totally normal and not functional-polluted.  Lisp is a multi-paradigm language, and is perfectly happy integrating things like OO into it without having to do backflips to fit it into a functional mold.

[13:31:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Everyone else's object system is just weak and annoying, is all.

[13:31:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
/me grumps.

[13:54:00.0000] <gsnedders>
You mean you don't love JS? :o

[13:54:01.0000] <gsnedders>
:P

[14:06:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[14:07:00.0000] <jgraham>
TabAtkins: Javascript hoists the function definitions to the top of the scope so you don't have to define things in order there

[14:07:01.0000] <jgraham>
But in python you can do all kinds of stuff like

[14:07:02.0000] <jgraham>
class Foo(Bar):

[14:08:00.0000] <jgraham>
  if baz:

[14:08:01.0000] <jgraham>
    def __init__(self):

[14:08:02.0000] <jgraham>
(and so on)

[14:08:03.0000] <jgraham>
  else:

[14:08:04.0000] <jgraham>
  def __init__(self):

[14:08:05.0000] <jgraham>
      (some other stuff)

[14:10:00.0000] <jgraham>
Not claiming that is really useful, but I have changed the metaclass based on whether logging is enabled by putting an if statement in the class body

[14:10:01.0000] <jgraham>
Dunno if this really interferes with the ability to lazily resolve symbols though

[14:11:00.0000] <broquaint>
There's also Joose, inspired by Moose, which was inspired by "The Art of the Meta Object Protocol" which in turn describes Lisp's CLOS :)

[14:18:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
JonathanNeal: No, not me.  Dunno where that came from.  ^_^

[14:19:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
jgraham: In Lisp all this talk of "methods" is silly.  You just have functions specialized on certain arguments.  You can certainly define different versions of a function in an if.

[14:20:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
(That said, Lisp certainly has "methods".  It reuses that name for functions specialized on their arguments.  ^_^)

[14:32:00.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: you don't have to define classes in perl before you use them

[14:32:01.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: it's all late-dispatch

[14:33:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
So Python's the stupid stepchild of dynamic languages here.

[14:33:01.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: you can even make a method that takes as an argument the name of the method that was called and have it dynamically make up the method as it goes

[14:33:02.0000] <Hixie>
and even in typed languages you don't have to give the full definition -- e.g. in objectpascal so long as you declare that the identifier will be defined as a class later, you can use it as a class before it's defined

[14:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
(the compiler does two passes, one to get the types and then one to get the code, or something)

[14:41:00.0000] <LoneStar99>

[14:42:00.0000] <LoneStar99>

[14:43:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes, every time you draw to <canvas>, it's completely fresh.  If you want to keep the old lines around, you have to remember them and redrew them in the next draw step.

[14:49:00.0000] <LoneStar99>

[14:59:00.0000] <LoneStar99>
TabAtkins:  is it still not working the link above?

[15:00:00.0000] <erlehmann>
i should be considered a hero http://github.com/erlehmann/wordpress/commit/f1d3dec90eb2ec18e973aa1e374ce78944a2fd68

[15:00:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
LoneStar99: Yeah.  It keeps saying your computer is offline.

[15:01:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
LoneStar99: Are you drawing it in the mouseMove so that the user can see the line before clicking the second time?

[15:02:00.0000] <LoneStar99>
TabAtkins: ok try this link http://freagair.com/RON/funky.png

[15:02:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah, that's what I thought.

[15:03:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Everything is acting normally, then.  You're just doing it wrong.  ^_^

[15:03:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
So, you're drawing it in the mouseMove so that people can see the line before releasing their mouse and committing to a second point.

[15:03:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
This means that, yes, you do indeed need to clear the canvas between draws and redraw the line, since you don't want the previous "preview" lines to persist.

[15:04:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
But that means that, obviously, you're clearing the canvas, and thus have to redraw *everything* you want to persist.

[15:04:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
So save the points of previous lines in an array or something and redraw them at every drawing step.

[15:05:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
This is the downside of immediate-mode graphics like <canvas>.  They have *no memory* of what's inside of them.  They're just a bag of dumb pixels.

[15:06:00.0000] <LoneStar99>
TabAtkins:  ok, makes sense....

[15:06:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
If you want to manipulate lines by themselves without worrying about previous lines you've drawn, you want a retained-mode graphics.  That is, SVG.

[15:06:02.0000] <erlehmann>
they kicked me out of #wordpress for this.

[15:06:03.0000] <erlehmann>
wtf

[15:07:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
In SVG, you'd just create a <line> or whatever element on mousedown and adjust its attributes on mouseMove.  Then when they mousedown again, you're creating a new element, which doesn't interact with the old one.

[15:07:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
erlehmann: Hahaha.

[15:07:03.0000] <aho>

[15:07:06.0000] <LoneStar99>

[15:08:00.0000] <erlehmann>
i'll go join the habari cabal right after gsoc. hello gsnedders.

[15:08:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
True that, aho.  To clarify, you can use the visible canvas as "scratch", copying the hidden canvas at every redraw (rather than just clearing the canvas).  Then, when the user commits to a particular line, draw that final line to the hidden canvas.

[15:09:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
That way the hidden canvas is only manipulated in an additive way, and never needs to be cleared, while the visible scratch canvas can be manipulated as much as you want.

[15:09:01.0000] <aho>
http://kaioa.com/k/ct/image_combine/index.html <- that renderToCanvas function creates such an off-screen canvas for example

[15:45:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, Hixie: looks like PHP also doesn't mind "$x = new A(); class A {...}".

[15:45:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It runs the constructor and everything.

[15:45:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Oh well, Python is picky.

[15:46:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Excellent.

[15:46:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It seems PHP just reads the whole file before it actually executes anything.

[15:48:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
This delays three seconds, prints "1\n2\n", then delays another three seconds: (echo '<?php echo "1\n";'; sleep 3; echo 'echo "2\n"; sleep(3);') | php

[15:48:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
(second delay to ensure that it's not just buffering output)

[15:51:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me can't think of any serious languages that don't read the whole file before actually executing anything

[15:51:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I assume "serious languages" is intended to exclude shells.  :)

[15:52:00.0000] <Philip`>
Yes, and BASICs

[15:53:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I see the same behavior in Python.  Don't really know any other interpreted languages to test in.

[15:56:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Why do they read the whole file first?

[15:56:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
For PHP, one reason is so they can run any require()s immediately.

[15:57:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I don't see why that would be necessary, if you actually executed statements in order.

[15:57:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Clearly PHP executes statements out of order, so of course it has to read the whole file first.

[15:57:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
require()s fire even if they're in a non-executed path.

[15:57:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
if(false) { require "foo" }, frex, still requires and runs "foo".

[15:57:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
But the code in the file you fetch doesn't actually execute, I assume.

[15:58:00.0000] <Philip`>
(I think the issue with Python is that class definitions are just code that's executed at runtime and bind to the class name, so if you have code that executes earlier then it hasn't been bound yet)

[15:58:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
It... might?

[15:59:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Philip`: Correct, Python's just not being smart enough about the binding.  You don't actually *need* a class there until you actuall interact with the object, you just need a handle.  Good object systems let you attach classes to that handle later.

[15:59:01.0000] <Philip`>
(It's fine to refer to classes that aren't syntactically earlier in the file, they just have to be dynamically earlier in runtime else you get a NameError when trying to use them)

[15:59:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Python has a weird object system.

[15:59:03.0000] <Philip`>
TabAtkins: How could it be smarter? Before it's executed the class definition, there is nothing it could reasonably bind to

[16:00:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Philip`: You tell me.  Tons of other dynamic languages get it right.

[16:01:00.0000] <Philip`>
Python lets you do 'print 1; class C: print 2; if thing_with_side_effects(): def method(): etc'

[16:01:01.0000] <Philip`>
and the code inside the class C definition gets executed after the first print statement

[16:01:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes.

[16:01:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
You can define classes conditionally in PHP, and it seems to work out.

[16:01:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
And in Lisp, and in Perl, and in...

[16:02:00.0000] <Philip`>
Other languages either work in effectively the same way (it's a runtime error if you use a class name that hasn't been bound), or are much more static (the class definitions can be extracted without executing the code)

[16:02:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, by the way, <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Protected_Areas_of_Colorado> is semantically a table, but not semantically a table in a table in a table.  :)

[16:03:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, I'm guessing that at least in PHP, it's not a runtime error if you use a class that hasn't been bound, as long as the class isn't defined conditionally.

[16:42:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
The real problem is that the language is meant to be a simple declarative thing, not an actual programming language.

[16:43:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[16:43:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[16:44:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[16:47:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[16:50:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[16:53:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[16:54:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Ah, true.

[16:54:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah, I imagine that a language *designed* to be an embedded scripting language running untrusted code would do so.

[19:16:00.0000] <drclue>
Here is something I would like to suggest that would make my life and probably that of others easier.  That would be two attributes added to at least the DIV and SPAN elements.  Those two attributes would be XML and XSL. It certainly would make doing XML/XSL trasforms more straight forward.

[19:16:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
What?

[19:16:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
What are you trying to do and how would this help?

[19:18:00.0000] <drclue>
Well, I personally have always liked using XSL templates against XML data and being able to simply assign the URLs to those attributes would greatly simplify using templates

[19:18:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
So what are you asking for to help you with that?

[19:20:00.0000] <drclue>
Basically I would like to see the attributes XML and XSL added to the spec , and then the browser vendors could tuck their proprietary methods of doing transforms behind those attributes , and authors could simply use the setAttribute methods to perform the manipulations

[19:21:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
So, again, what are you actually trying to do?

[19:22:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'm hearing something about taking XML from somewhere, and specifying an XSL transform to apply to it.  Presumably the result will then render somewhere.

[19:24:00.0000] <drclue>
I'm not sure I understand the question, but what I'm trying to do is drum up some support for the thought of making XML/XSL more accessible in a standards based way , so that when driving dynamic displays , I can simply reference the url of the XML source and the XSL view and not always have to carry a bunch of browser object sniffing code to perform dynamic transforms.

[19:24:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
What do you mean "the attributes XML and XSL"?

[19:26:00.0000] <drclue>
<div XML="http://...." XSL="http://" />   

[19:27:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Um, what are those supposed to do?

[19:30:00.0000] <drclue>
The XSL attribute specifies an external XSL stylesheet to apply to the XML data referenced by the XML attribute. In the absence of the XSL attribute , the browser would first look to the XML file itself for a style reference and then fall through to the native rendering of the XML tree.

[19:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
You can already do client-side XSL.

[19:34:00.0000] <drclue>
Yes I can already do client-side XML/XSL, but it suffers from vendor specific hacks that could be neatly tucked away by giving some attributes for that purpose

[19:42:00.0000] <drclue>
I really don't see any downside in affording a more effective way to integrate XML/XSL w3.org standards in a page. The bandwidth savings afforded by XSL are hard to deny. The promotion of MVC techniques associated with XML/XSL is a positive thing too. Affording browser vendors a cheap way to standardize is a big bonus too.

[19:43:00.0000] <variable>
if I want to propose a new CSS attribute on text "gender: male; or gender: female;" for spoken media - where is the appropriate place to do so?

[19:43:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
variable, www-style.

[19:43:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
drclue, if vendor-specific hacks are required, then that should be fixed by itself.  You don't need a totally new way of including XSL to do that.

[19:44:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
And there is a cost for implementing every feature.  "There's no downside" isn't sufficient reason to get anything added to the spec.  It's long enough already.

[19:45:00.0000] <variable>

[19:45:01.0000] <variable>
I thought only people who have issues on the list can vote :|

[19:46:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
What?

[19:46:01.0000] <variable>
"Only people who have sent feedback that has ended up on this list are able to vote." --> I can vote but I don't see any of my emails 

[19:48:00.0000] <drclue>
@AryehGregor  Just by itself , those XML XSL attributes would have significant value. The fact that providing  a standards based way of doing something also ditches the need to use proprietary methods is added gravey

[19:48:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
You can include XSL without proprietary methods.

[19:48:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
<link rel=stylesheet href=mystylesheet.xsl>

[19:48:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
If browsers don't all support that, that won't be fixed by making up new attributes that mean a similar thing.

[19:51:00.0000] <drclue>
That would be a page wide item.  Elements in pages appear dynamically and get included in a wide variety of ways. Being able to specify the XML data and the XSL structure at the element level allows for better compartmentalization and a more effect way to draw in units of information into a page

[19:52:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Okay, well, send it to the list if you like.  I suggest you focus on use-cases rather than solutions.

If one sees integration of data and presentation in an element of a page, those XML/XSL attributes could handle the vast majority of it.

[00:21:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hsivonen: do you have any thoughts of whether any HTML elements should be allowed in <annotation-xml> ?

[00:21:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
or, more importantly, if the parsing algorithm should be changed to allow them there

[00:21:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9887

[00:22:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Simon suggested that maybe they could be dealt with by requiring they be wrapped in a <div>

[00:23:00.0000] <hsivonen>
MikeSmith: I'm OK with making <div> (maybe <span>, too, just in case?) magic there, but what's the use case?

[00:23:01.0000] <hsivonen>
hmm. actually, <div> is less dangerous, since it is scoping on its own right

[00:24:00.0000] <hsivonen>
MikeSmith: even without a use case now, I'd be OK with making <div> magic there in case a use case shows up later

[00:24:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
hsivonen: the use case is for using HTML to annotate MathML expressions in the same way that SVG or MathML itself can be used for such... but that said, I don't really understand the general use case for annotating MathML expressions to begin with

[00:25:00.0000] <hsivonen>
MikeSmith: the best use case I've seen for annotations is using SVG to draw notation that MathML itself doesn't support

[00:25:01.0000] <hsivonen>
dunno how HTML would help there

[00:27:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hsivonen: and even for that use case, couldn't SVG just be used within an <mtext> element, with no need to use the whole <semtantics>/<annotation-xml> apparatus?

[00:32:00.0000] <hsivonen>
MikeSmith: if the validity definition is adjusted, sure

[00:34:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hsivonen: we have the freedom to adjust the validity definition

[00:34:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
to define it in the HTML5 spec

[00:34:02.0000] <hsivonen>
MikeSmith: works for me

[00:37:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
but getting back to annotation-xml, I guess I'm just wondering whether it is worth the trouble to try to convince implementors and Hixie that changing the parsing algorithm to allow <div> (and/or <span>) within annotation-xml as a holder for HTML content is worth the effort

[00:37:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
it sounds like you're amenable at least

[00:38:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I can ask the MathML WG if they have use cases for HTML content in annotation-xml

[00:39:00.0000] <Hixie>
i think allowing just <div> would just end up confusing authors

[00:39:01.0000] <Hixie>
if we allow only one HTML element it should be <body> (or <html>)

[00:40:00.0000] <Hixie>
nessy: actually with WebSRT and the CSS extensions to address individual bits of the text cues, that's more or less possible

[00:40:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: Degrade Gracefully...

[00:41:00.0000] <Hixie>
hsivonen: both of those would degrade fine if no attributes are present

[00:41:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: <div> is the new <body>. see Atom

[00:41:02.0000] <Hixie>
Atom is not an example of good language design

[00:41:03.0000] <Hixie>
(it's not especially terrible, but it's not what i would suggest we base our decisions on)

[00:42:00.0000] <othermaciej>
<body> doesn't seem like a good element for other languages to use when embedding a snippet of HTML

[00:42:01.0000] <othermaciej>
for one thing, it means that when you nest that element back in HTML, you get nested <body>, which is pretty confusing

[00:42:02.0000] <othermaciej>
second, there shouldn't be an expectation that a snippet is necessarily like a complete document

[00:43:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(though really you'd want <html> if you are claiming to provide a complete embedded HTML document)

[00:43:01.0000] <drclue>

[00:45:00.0000] <Hixie>

[00:45:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:47:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[02:37:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[02:37:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: which I fixed by putting manifests on the speculative load side channel

[02:37:02.0000] <hsivonen>
since manifest processing doesn't really need the DOM node 

[02:37:03.0000] <Hixie>
what the manifest loading can be sync

[02:37:04.0000] <Hixie>

[02:38:00.0000] <Hixie>

[02:39:00.0000] <Hixie>

[02:39:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: what I'm saying is that stuff broke when we had speculative script loads start before the app cache stuff knew it's going to be seeing a manifest

[02:39:02.0000] <Peter`>

[02:39:03.0000] <hsivonen>

[02:40:00.0000] <Hixie>
hsivonen: it doesn't need to see the manifest, it just needs to know which cache to load files from, which is keyed from the manifest string -- no network or disk I/O needs to happen to do the processing necessary to prepare the browser for handling loads due to a manifest="" attribute

[03:53:01.0000] <annevk>

[03:54:00.0000] <annevk>

[03:54:01.0000] <annevk>

[04:30:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[04:33:00.0000] <s0enke>
hsivonen, they all do. but at least in PHP, rfc1867 gives you powerful features like validating the request, putting the data into a tmpfile, creating a $_FILES array with all the metadata. In a normal post, you'd have to stream the content into a file in userland context (and blow up your server memory). the c context is universes more efficient.

[04:35:00.0000] <hsivonen>
streaming to a file blowing up server memory seems like an indication of something being very wrong

[04:36:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[04:36:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[15:09:01.0000] <Hixie>

[15:11:00.0000] <Hixie>
ap: we're not adding both, that's just dumb. Either we should use .URL throughout or .url throughout (except Document), but either way you and mozilla need to decide which it is and stick to it.

[15:12:00.0000] <Hixie>
ap: you can ship a point update with this change if it's going to be that long until the next update

[15:12:01.0000] <ap>
Hixie: we shipped something that matched the draft spec, is there a good reason for it to change under us? this seems like a completely arbitrary change

[15:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
well first, drafts spec are subject to change at a whim, you know that. that's the risk of being on the cutting edge. Like I said, we're still considering a completely new protocol to replace the current websocket one.

[15:14:00.0000] <Hixie>
but the reason for this change was a discussion on public-webapps which had people from webkit, mozilla, and opera and which decided that we should consistently use lowercase attribute names so as to not make authors go crazy trying to work out what was lowercase and what was uppercase

[15:14:01.0000] <Hixie>
the minimum change was to change from URL to url

[15:14:02.0000] <Hixie>
going the other way would have required even more implementations to change

[15:16:00.0000] <ap>
Hixie: XMLHttpRequest is also a draft, let's maybe change it to XMLHTTPRequest for consistency?

[15:17:00.0000] <Hixie>
XMLHttpRequest isn't a draft, it was shipped in like 1999

[15:17:01.0000] <ap>
Hixie: I think that there should be a cost/benefit analysis be applied, even to bleeding edge drafts

[15:17:02.0000] <Hixie>
there is

[15:17:03.0000] <Hixie>
and here the cost is MASSIVELY more on the side of being inconsistent

[15:17:04.0000] <ap>
there is no consistency in "url" casing on the Web, is there?

[01:07:03.0000] <abarth>

[01:07:04.0000] <abarth>
it's just a difference in the processing model from the actual processing

[01:08:00.0000] <abarth>
the problem with nested event loops

[01:08:01.0000] <abarth>
is you get in trouble when you try to unwind them

[01:08:02.0000] <abarth>
because lots of stuff gets re-entered

[01:08:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
ah

[01:08:04.0000] <abarth>
that might not be expecting it

[01:08:05.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah, I can imagine

[01:08:06.0000] <abarth>
the parser needs to be re-entrant, which makes it tricky

[01:09:00.0000] <abarth>
DOM mutation also needs to be re-entrant, which is really hard'

[01:09:01.0000] <abarth>
and the source of lots of bugs :(

[01:09:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
that I also can imagine

[01:10:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
or actually, remember

[01:10:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
from previous life in browser product development

[08:43:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[08:44:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
There's disagreement about how text-shadow works *right now*, which is weird.

[08:45:00.0000] <Philip`>
Reverse-engineering shadow algorithms is fun

[08:45:01.0000] <Philip`>
/me wonders how similar CSS shadows are to canvas shadows

[08:46:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
canvas shadows are an exact copy of webkit's bugs in css shadows.

[08:47:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Including a substantial change in shadow algorithm when the shadow blur is > 8px.

[08:48:00.0000] <Philip`>
Does it do the slightly weird thing with sigma=sqrt(2*blur) if blur>8 ?

[08:48:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
So, yes.

[08:48:02.0000] <Philip`>
That's not a substantial change, it's just interpreting the argument a bit differently

[08:48:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
It makes things weird, at least.

[08:48:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
smfr was complaining about it.

[08:49:00.0000] <Philip`>
It makes the shadow appear to scale more linearly, without big visual differences between small integers, if I remember correctly

[08:50:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I was told it was a performance optimization.

[08:50:01.0000] <Philip`>
I assume the behaviour was inherited from CG, rather than being an intentional WebKit feature

[08:50:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah, I assume so.

[08:51:00.0000] <Philip`>
(I assume by "webkit's bugs" you meant the CG port of WebKit)

[08:51:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[08:51:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
I dunno, I'm just paraphrasing from smfr.

[08:55:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[08:55:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[09:19:00.0000] <Philip`>
Hmm, why does text-shadow indicate the blur is measured in pixels?

[09:20:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Where does it do so?

[09:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
Isn't that slightly meaningless, since the blur is theoretically infinite in size and I assume the specified size is not equal to the Gaussian sigma

[09:21:01.0000] <Philip`>
"text-shadow: 0 0 100px black;"

[09:22:00.0000] <Philip`>
(s/$/?/ in earlier question)

[09:22:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
The blur length specifies how far you have to go before the blur has gotten to within 1% of the full color/full transparency.  Or at least, that's probably what we're specifying now.

[09:22:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
It is remarkably underspecified right now.

[09:23:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
So yeah, the blur is theoretically infinite, but the area within the threshold isn't.

[09:23:01.0000] <Philip`>
1% in what colour space?

[09:23:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
rgb, the default css color space

[09:24:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[09:29:00.0000] <karlushi>

[09:30:00.0000] <Philip`>
TabAtkins: Doesn't "1% of the full color" mean you need to solve a cubic equation to work out what sigma to use for the Gaussian, or am I getting my maths all wrong?

[09:30:01.0000] <Philip`>
(I'm interpreting it as meaning G(x) = 0.01 as defined by http://upload.wikimedia.org/math/b/5/a/b5a3ab06a75210694218bcbd7370eea3.png)

[09:32:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Philip`: I have no clue.

[09:32:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
But I'm certain there's a much faster approximation.

[09:35:00.0000] <Philip`>
So the text-shadow property will be giving an approximation of an arbitrary percentage threshold?

[09:36:00.0000] <Philip`>
That doesn't sound very mathematically sane :-(

[09:36:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Who cares about math, we're doing webdesign.

[09:37:00.0000] <jgraham>
TabAtkins: Seems like a good idea to understand the maths before you specify something insane

[09:38:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
To be fair, it appears that the implementors who're paying attention are cool with all that anyway.

[09:39:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The only question is whether a 100px blur length means that the full blur area (extending inside and outside of the unblurred shadow boundary) is 100px wide, or that the blur area must extend 100px inside and outside.

[09:39:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
And that's just a question of bikeshedding and convergence with sufficiently related technologies, luckily.

[09:40:00.0000] <Philip`>
Is canvas sufficiently related?

[09:40:01.0000] <Philip`>
(I think that has a mathematically reasonably sane definition of shadow rendering :-) )

[09:40:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Only insofar as canvas is literally "whatever webkit did for shadows".

[09:40:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
So, since we're already considering webkit, canvas just weights that slightly.

[09:41:00.0000] <annevk>
MikeSmith, still around?

[09:41:01.0000] <jgraham>
/me would have assumed that the blur length would be defined as a sigma of a given number of pixels, or something

[09:41:02.0000] <jgraham>
/me has no idea how it actually works though

[09:41:03.0000] <Philip`>
It's not precisely what Safari did, since Safari had (has?) incorrect clipping for small shadow sizes

[09:41:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
jgraham: Your average web author has absolutely no idea what a sigma is.

[09:41:05.0000] <Philip`>
(It would cut off the leftmost pixel of the shadow, in a visible way)

[09:41:06.0000] <jgraham>
TabAtkins: So?

[09:42:00.0000] <jgraham>
TabAtkins: Presumably they just adjust until they get the result they want

[09:42:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
So we want the blur length to mean something reasonable?

[09:42:02.0000] <Philip`>
TabAtkins: They just need to know that it's correlated to the apparent width of the shadow

[09:42:03.0000] <jgraham>
It does mean something reasonable

[09:42:04.0000] <Philip`>
(It can never be equal to the width since the shadow doesn't have an edge)

[09:43:00.0000] <jgraham>
It means that the shadow is 1/e of the maximum value at that number of pixels

[09:43:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's putting implementor interests over author interests, for little benefit to implementors and measurable downside to authors.

[09:43:02.0000] <jgraham>
I challenge you to measure that downside

[09:43:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
I did.  It's -13 utilons.

[09:43:04.0000] <jgraham>
I don't see why an author cares if it is 1/e or 1/100

[09:44:00.0000] <annevk>
MikeSmith, I fixed that and some other issues

[09:44:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
An author cares that the language is predictable.  Saying "well, bigger numbers mean bigger shadows" is only *barely* acceptable.  Ideally, the author shoudl be able to predict how large the shadow will be for a given length.

[09:45:00.0000] <jgraham>
The shadows will be infinitely big, apart from hardware limitations

[09:45:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Now you're being pedantic.

[09:46:00.0000] <jgraham>
Not really :)

[09:46:01.0000] <jgraham>
I mean, in theory, there is no edge of the shadow.

[09:46:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
The measure we're planning to use on defining the "edge" of the shadow is 1% from full color/full transparency.

[09:47:00.0000] <jgraham>
/me would really use n sigma for integer n

[09:47:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
The two are interchangeable.

[09:47:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Also, we dont' specify the blurring algorithm, so we can't assume a gaussian blur.

[09:48:00.0000] <jgraham>
I assume no one will implement a non-gaussian blur

[09:48:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
If you just wanted to use 3 sigma, that's fine.

[09:48:02.0000] <jgraham>
If they did it would be even weirder

[09:48:03.0000] <Philip`>
How can you specify shadowing without specifying the blurring algorithm?

[09:48:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Man, I dunno.  I just know there was pushback against us specifying a precise algo.

[09:49:00.0000] <Philip`>
That seems to be basically leaving the entire thing undefined

[09:49:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Philip`: Barely.  We just define the boundaries, and then say there should be a gradient of some kind.

[09:51:00.0000] <Philip`>
So someone could e.g. do a 100%-to-0% radial gradient around the edge of the shape, so that a tiny dot would have as bright a shadow as a large box?

[09:51:01.0000] <Philip`>
That doesn't sound good for interoperability

[09:51:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
See: pushback against specifying a precise algo.

[09:52:00.0000] <jgraham>
TabAtkins: It needen't bee to precise

[09:52:01.0000] <Philip`>
(Either people will implement things very differently, which is bad for interop, or they'll implement it the same anyway, in which case it can be specced)

[09:52:02.0000] <jgraham>
It should say "implementation defined approximation to a gaussian blur" or something

[09:53:00.0000] <jgraham>
You could argue that anything is an approximation to a gaussian of course, but that would be deliberatly perverse

[09:53:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Time for conference call!

[09:54:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me just thinks it seems crazy to specify a rendering behaviour without actually specifying the rendering behaviour

[09:57:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I agree, actually.

[15:53:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[15:53:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[15:53:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[15:53:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me reads the Unicode spec

[16:00:00.0000] <Hixie>
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=91bNp7HJolE

[16:05:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, looks like U+002F SOLIDUS is in the class "SY: Symbols Allowing Break After (A)", so breaks should occur after it except if it immediately precedes a digit.

[16:05:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
"URLs are now so common in regular plain text that they need to be taken into account when assigning general-purpose line breaking properties. Slash (solidus) is allowed as an additional, limited break opportunity to improve layout of Web addresses. As a side effect, some common abbreviations such as “w/o” or “A/S”, which normally would not be broken, acquire a line break opportunity. The recommendation in this case is for the layout 

[16:05:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
system not to utilize a line break opportunity allowed by SY unless the distance between it and the next line break opportunity exceeds an implementation-defined minimal distance.

[16:05:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
"

[16:05:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Ack, too long.

[16:06:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
K, so we're not following unicode.  That's cool.

[16:06:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
FWIW, IE doesn't follow that either.  However, it puts a linebreak opportunity before [, so it still ends up wrapping that line sufficiently.

[16:06:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
The full algorithm looks quite complicated.  I suspect browsers don't implement it for some reason.

[16:07:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
For instance, it says that breaks are permitted before %, but not if it's preceded by a number, even if there's intervening whitespace.

[16:07:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me tests that

[16:08:00.0000] <Philip`>
http://canvex.lazyilluminati.com/83b/play.xhtml - yay, Canvex sort of works in IE9, if I disable the SVG <object>s (otherwise it doesn't seem to load the wall textures) and do s/const/var/ in the JS

[16:08:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Firefox 3.7, Chrome dev, and Opera 10.60 all ignore that.

[16:10:00.0000] <Philip`>
Still drops down to ~15fps in Ultra size when moving, though :-(

[16:11:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me can't figure out how [ is supposed to be handled

[16:11:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It looks like "(AL | NU) × OP" means "do not break between an alphanumeric character and an opening punctuation character".

[16:17:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hmm, it seems like the prose contradicts the actual algorithm?

[16:17:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's not surprising.

[16:17:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Oh, no, I see.

[16:17:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's covered by the last rule, "Break everywhere else."

[16:18:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It actually looks to be very thorough and well-considered.

[16:18:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
The algorithm, I mean.

[16:18:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's cool.

[16:18:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Although as with some other Unicode algorithms, it concedes that you may have to tailor it for best results.

[19:17:00.0000] <boblet>
re: CSS I was told UAs can’t drop vendor prefixes until the relevant spec goes CR. Given border-radius on Opera even though CSS3 Backgrounds is still Working Draft, that’s wrong, no?

[19:18:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Backgrounds went CR for a short time.

[19:18:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
And then we pulled it back to make some useful changes.

[19:19:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
It should be back to Last Call any time now, too.

[19:19:01.0000] <boblet>
TabAtkins: aaah, that explains it. so regarding adding non-prefixed versions to ‘future-proof’ (like for transitions), is that bad? (given the spec could change etc)

[19:22:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes and no.  It's good, and it's bad, and it's good and bad to do the opposite.

[19:22:01.0000] <boblet>
lol

[19:22:02.0000] <boblet>
thanks for your definitive answer :)

[19:22:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
If you put in unprefixed versions, figuring that they won't change, you create some pressure to not change it, since you have deployed content that won't be compatible.

[19:22:04.0000] <boblet>
(it certainly covered all the bases)

[19:23:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
But if you don't, then you make it more painful to drop prefixed versions, since you might not update your site to use the unprefixed one.

[19:23:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
So, shrug?

[19:23:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
I use unprefixed, but only if I'm using the property in a simple enough manner that I'm confident it won't change.

[19:24:00.0000] <boblet>
yeah, I personally work on the expectation that most specs won’t change significantly, and if there is a major change it’ll be something I notice and then go fix

[19:25:00.0000] <erlehmann>
i use prefixes. after all, that is what they are for.

[19:25:01.0000] <boblet>
there’s no site (that I know of) tracking what browsers are or have been using prefixes, so it’s hard to keep on top of adding unprefixed versions in

[19:25:02.0000] <erlehmann>
boblet, progressive degradation or how it is called ;)

[19:25:03.0000] <erlehmann>
make your site work without fancy backgrounds, problem solved

[19:26:00.0000] <boblet>
erlehmann: graceful degredation ;-)

[19:26:01.0000] <boblet>

[09:57:02.0000] <Philip`>

[09:58:00.0000] <Philip`>

[09:58:01.0000] <Philip`>

[09:59:00.0000] <taptapir>

[09:59:01.0000] <Philip`>
Yeah, you could use <body onload> too if you know all the images before the page has first finished loading

[10:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
If you have 1000 images, and each time an image loads you loop through all 1000 images to check whether they're all loaded yet, you'll be doing 10^6 checks

[10:01:00.0000] <Philip`>
(though if you have 1000 images you should stick them in a texture atlas or something so that you don't have 1000 images :-) )

taptapir: Every function call always runs to completion

[10:25:00.0000] <Philip`>
The asynchronous bit is like in 'img.onload = function () { do something }' - that's just defining a function, not executing it, and then storing it somewhere (in the image) and carrying on

[10:25:01.0000] <Philip`>
and some time after that script has finished, the browser will decide to call the function you stored in onload

[10:26:00.0000] <Philip`>
JS itself doesn't do anything asynchronous - it just registers callbacks with the browser environment

[10:26:01.0000] <Philip`>
effectively

[10:26:02.0000] <taptapir>
hmm, I started some javascript books yesterday but none of them seems to mention the async nature of it. any good books/sources you can recommend?

[10:26:03.0000] <Philip`>
/me doesn't know of any

[10:27:00.0000] <Philip`>
Are you familiar with function pointers and callbacks in C?

[10:27:01.0000] <taptapir>
yep

[10:28:00.0000] <Philip`>
It's basically the same thing, except instead of using a function pointer like "&function_that_does_stuff" you can define it inline like "function() { do stuff }"

[10:30:00.0000] <taptapir>
finally! thanks I get it a little bit better now

[10:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
(You can also do "function do_stuff() { do stuff }; ... img.onload = do_stuff;" which is equivalent to "img.onload = function() { do stuff }")

[10:31:01.0000] <taptapir>
yeah the first one is more C like :)

[10:31:02.0000] <Philip`>
(except in the latter case the function can refer to variables in its container scope)

[10:31:03.0000] <taptapir>
inline callbacks, that made sense.

[10:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
JS books should talk about closures, which are the relevant thing here

[10:32:01.0000] <taptapir>
checking...

[10:33:00.0000] <taptapir>
yes it's mentioned, I'm not there yet though. I'll pay special attention to that chapter

[10:34:00.0000] <Philip`>
I think they're a slightly strange concept when coming from C, but pretty useful once you understand them properly :-)

[10:35:00.0000] <taptapir>
got it! thanks Philip`and zcorpan_

[12:16:00.0000] <taptapir>
in JS, functions are objects right?

[12:16:01.0000] <taptapir>
howcome "document.body.insertAdjacentElement(document.createElement("div").innerHTML = "ljkghljkg");" is illegal?

[12:18:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The return value of 'document.createElement("div").innerHTML = "ljkghljkg"' isn't a valid arg for insertAdjacentElement().

[12:18:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
This isn't jQuery, where everything returns a reasonable value for chaining.  ^_^

[12:27:00.0000] <taptapir>
arghh, right sry

[12:30:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Was your "functions are objects" question unrelated?

[12:31:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Because yes, they are.  And most objects are functions, so you can get a constructor.

[12:32:00.0000] <ayapo>
woah, just checked out the site hosting the irc logs. The yellow highlight function is epic awesome.

[12:34:00.0000] <taptapir>
TabAtkins: i thought the createElement().innetHTML part was the illegal one so I was assuming that createElement was not an object.

[12:34:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Ah, that's unrelated.  createElement() returns a Node object.

[12:37:00.0000] <taptapir>
what's a node object? html tags?

[12:37:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah, it's a class that represents an element in the DOM.  Also other things, like text or comments.

[12:46:00.0000] <paul_irish>
boblet proposed using css transitions and transforms without the prefix (in addition to the prefixed variants) as the spec isnt likely to change and end users are unlikely to update their code when the spec hits CR... 

[12:46:01.0000] <paul_irish>
i can totally see that POV but i've been holding off on going unprefixed for un-cr things so far..

[12:47:00.0000] <paul_irish>
anyone here take a side on that?

[12:47:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
As long as you're willing to go back and fix your code, there's no problem.

[12:47:02.0000] <hsivonen>
yes, there is

[12:47:03.0000] <hsivonen>
implementors don't know if your site is maintained by a person who is willing to adjust

[12:47:04.0000] <paul_irish>
i can handle either case, i just want to make the right recommendation to other developers.

[12:47:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
/me wants to write a mixin spec for CSS which would solve the prefix problem without the problems of removing them entirely.

[12:48:00.0000] <paul_irish>
who are likely a lot more lazy

[12:48:01.0000] <hsivonen>
(I use unprefixed stuff myself, though.)

[12:48:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
hsivonen: But going with or without prefixes both cause problems for implementors.

[12:48:03.0000] <taptapir>
let's say I create an image in JS and point it to a PNG file in the server with _.src property, when does the browser actually starts to download it? also when the image.onload event occurs, does it mean that the download is finished or that the image is in the memory? or do I make any kind of sense :)

[12:48:04.0000] <hsivonen>
TabAtkins: indeed, I use unprefixed versions partly in protest against long-term prefixing

[12:49:00.0000] <paul_irish>

[12:49:01.0000] <hsivonen>
yeah

[12:49:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Animation's complex enough that I wouldn't unprefix it.  Too much change of *something* changing underneath you.

[12:49:03.0000] <paul_irish>
For sure. thx guys

[12:50:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
And yeah, the convo's died down somewhat, but I'm agitating for some changes to animations.

[12:50:01.0000] <Philip`>
taptapir: It could start to download in the background as soon as you set .src, though I don't know whether browsers will wait for the current script to return first

[12:51:00.0000] <Philip`>
taptapir: onload will be called some time (probably immediately) after the image is downloaded and decoded and found to not have errors (else it'll call onerror instead, I think), and you can safely use the image for drawing in canvases etc after that

[12:52:00.0000] <taptapir>
Philip`: so in this phase image is still not read to the memory right?

[12:53:00.0000] <Philip`>
taptapir: Depends on what you mean by being in memory

[12:54:00.0000] <Philip`>
taptapir: Browsers are free to do whatever optimisations they want in terms of caching data in memory, lazy decoding, etc, so you can never really know what they're doing - you just know whether or not it's safe to perform certain actions on images (like drawing them)

[12:55:00.0000] <taptapir>
I mean, is the image data transferred to a buffer in the memory? or is it simply presented by something like file pointers in C?

[12:56:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Again, you don't know, because browsers are allowed to do what they want.  All you know is that certain actions are allowed at specific points.

[12:56:01.0000] <Philip`>
It's been downloaded from the network (so you can use it immediately), but everything else is just implementation details that you shouldn't need to know about

[12:57:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
annevk, the entire IE compatibility list thing can be fairly described as "hard to do", but IE has to do it anyway, since they have to deal with IE-only sites and IE-only code paths, so if they just implemented standards without compatibility they'd break.  (See: IE7.)

[12:57:01.0000] <taptapir>
Philip`: you know I want to download my game assets before the game starts,  what I wonder is that if I do that will it fill up the memory?

[12:57:02.0000] <taptapir>
lets say for 1000 images

[12:58:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Everyone else tends to get the same code paths in most cases, due to "develop your site for standards-compliant browsers, then fix for IE".  So they can converge on a common behavior without causing more bugs than they prevent, usually.

[12:58:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
IE9's goal is explicitly to work with the same exact code everyone else gets, so hopefully IE10 won't need an IE9 compatibility mode.

[13:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
taptapir: That's an implementation detail :-)

[13:01:00.0000] <Philip`>
taptapir: It seems plausible that some implementations would store all loaded images as decoded RGBA in RAM, so you don't want to load huge amounts of image data and just hope the browser will do something clever with it

[13:02:00.0000] <taptapir>
Philip`: I better load each levels' assets when the time to use comes just to be safe then.

[13:02:01.0000] <Philip`>
taptapir: Depends on whether you're talking about megabytes or hundreds of megabytes or gigabytes of decoded image data

[13:03:00.0000] <Philip`>
taptapir: (If you're using them with WebGL then you have to worry about VRAM too, which is much more limited than RAM+swap)

[13:03:01.0000] <taptapir>
exactly

[13:03:02.0000] <taptapir>

[13:03:03.0000] <taptapir>

[13:07:00.0000] <Philip`>
The web environment is not designed to provide much control of resource usage (since it's meant to provide portability instead, which means taking resource control away from authors and leaving it to browser developers), so if you want to push the boundaries then you'll just have to do lots of experimentation and make browser-specific assumptions

[13:56:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think there would be a few steps required to make them into appropriate tests for a standards test suite:

[13:57:00.0000] <othermaciej>
1) ensure that everything tested is associated with specific conformance requirements in the spec

[13:57:01.0000] <othermaciej>
2) annotate the tests with the relevant conformance requirements

[13:57:02.0000] <othermaciej>
3) convert to whatever format the w3c wants them in

[13:57:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:58:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[13:58:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[16:39:00.0000] <Hixie>

[16:40:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Drop on the floor?

[16:41:00.0000] <Hixie>
the whole cue up to the next double blank line?

[16:41:01.0000] <Hixie>
that's kinda what i figured should happen

[16:41:02.0000] <Hixie>
other options are to just ignore the one line and try reading a timestamp from the next one

[16:41:03.0000] <Hixie>
or to drop the whole file from there on

[16:42:00.0000] <Hixie>
or to assume a timestamp of 0

[16:42:01.0000] <Hixie>
or of equal to the last timestamp seen

[16:43:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I don't think anything that assumes a timestamp would be good.

[16:43:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Dropping the whole file is no good either, if the rest is properly formatted.

[16:43:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Ignoring just that line and trying the next sounds potentially cool.

[16:44:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
So, one of those two.  Either skip the line, or skip everything until the next double blank line.

[16:45:00.0000] <Hixie>
i guess skip the block is safest
