[19:03:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
a question

[19:04:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
an answer

[19:04:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
heh

[19:04:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
why is it that WebGL needs TypedArray but canvas 2D context does not?

[19:05:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
what's different about that 3D api that requires binary support?

[19:05:01.0000] <Philip`>
The only large arrays in the 2D context are pixel arrays, which are just arrays of octets and therefore easy

[19:05:02.0000] <Philip`>
3D needs large arrays of floats (vertex coordinates), shorts (vertex array indices), etc

[19:06:00.0000] <Philip`>
and large arrays of different types interleaved

[19:06:01.0000] <Philip`>
(so each array element can encode all the data for a vertex)

[19:08:00.0000] <othermaciej>
yeah, ImageData is in fact a typed array

[19:08:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it's just that you don't need more than that

[19:27:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Philip`, othermaciej - I see, thanks

[19:28:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I think it would be good for vlad to consider adding that as informative background to the Introduction section of the TypedArray spec

[19:31:00.0000] <Hixie>
how should i detect if a file is an SRT file: by a whitelist of MIME types, by searching for --> on the second non-blank line, by looking for a magic string (which would work for WebSRT but would mean plain SRT files need a trivial modification to be used), some combination thereof, or by some other mechanism?

[19:33:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
le

[19:33:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
it would seem like something that did not rely on sniffing would be preferable

[19:33:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
so, whitelist of MIME types

[19:33:03.0000] <Hixie>
that's still a kind of sniffing

[19:34:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
OK, so that type

[19:34:01.0000] <Hixie>
k

[19:34:02.0000] <Hixie>
(the problem with "sniffing" is not that it's in-band, but that it's not interoperable)

[19:34:03.0000] <Hixie>
(this would be interoperable)

[19:35:00.0000] <Hixie>
if there's no MIME type, do I assume WebSRT or do I bail?

[19:38:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
playing devil's advocate for architectural-purity/sanity advocates: I guess I would suggest that you bail

[19:38:01.0000] <Hixie>
well there are quite practical reasons to bail too

[19:38:02.0000] <Hixie>
i just don't know if they overwhelm the practical reasons not to bail

[19:38:03.0000] <Hixie>
in practice, most resources have a mime type

[19:38:04.0000] <Hixie>
it's rare that none be given

[19:39:00.0000] <Hixie>
(it's usually text/plain or text/html, if it's wrong)

[19:40:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think any fallback behavior is ok as long as it's defined

[19:40:01.0000] <othermaciej>
whether that is hard fail or some kind of sniffing

[19:40:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah but I guess they are not so rare enough to have not cause serious problems in the past

[19:40:03.0000] <othermaciej>
the interop problem is mainly if you don't define it

[19:40:04.0000] <Hixie>
indeed

[19:40:05.0000] <MikeSmith>
e.g., like that Apache default being to treat everything as text/plain even it if doesn't have a MIME type

[19:40:06.0000] <othermaciej>
which is why so much video still gets served as text/plain

[19:41:00.0000] <othermaciej>
the more kinds of resources get sniffed, the harder it is to verify that the full set of sniffing algorithms does not have holes

[19:41:01.0000] <othermaciej>
therefore I would advocate not doing sniffing for new kinds of formats if there isn't a deep need for it

[19:41:02.0000] <othermaciej>
(and by "holes" I mean opportunity to make things get sniffed multiple ways to create a security hole)

[19:42:00.0000] <Hixie>
makes sense

[19:42:01.0000] <Hixie>
i guess

[19:42:02.0000] <Hixie>
i dunno

[19:42:03.0000] <Hixie>
i kinda like unambiguously self-describing formats

[19:43:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
in general for new specs it seems like the most sane thing for interop is being as unforgiving as possible

[19:43:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
and keep the option open of adding forgiveness later

[19:47:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I wonder if the Typed Arrays spec draft is the first to ever include a section explicitly titled with "Bikeshedding"

[19:47:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
regardless, I like it. So I hope it starts a trend

[19:54:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[19:55:00.0000] <Hixie>

[21:00:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[13:20:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
for those interested in e-books, and/or specifically in the ePub format -

[13:20:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
http://www.idpf.org/idpf_groups/IDPF-EPUB-WG-Charter-4-27-2010.html

[13:20:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
see the Preliminary Solutions section

[13:21:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
where it lists "Adopt HTML5 Features"

[13:22:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
also see "Current Industry Problems" the list of problems that they are trying to address with this 2.1 update to ePub

[13:22:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
e.g., "Need for enhanced global language support"

[13:23:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
and specific mention of "including but not limited to special line-breaking rules and vertical writing direction"

[13:23:01.0000] <Hixie>
"it is acknowledged that a number of significant issues would need to be resolved" i wonder what those are

[13:24:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
dunno

[13:24:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
but we can try to find out

[13:25:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
they seem to be taking a fairly pragmatic approach to this update

[13:25:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
so far

[13:25:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
e.g., see the statement, "Since most distributed Reading Systems utilize Web browsers to present content to end users, and many standalone Reading Systems utilize Web browser rendering technologies in their implementations, it is desirable to improve alignment with Web standards as implemented by modern browsers."

[13:26:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
"as implemented"

[13:26:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
as opposed to, say, "as we would have preferred them to have been implemented"

[13:27:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
or "as not implemented yet but we will spec things out on the basis of blind faith"

[13:28:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
keep in mind that ePub 2.0 is normatively based on XHTML 1.1

[13:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
they seem to have done a reasonable job overall of being pragmatic within the constraints of not being experts in web tech

[13:28:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah

[13:29:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
and switching away from XHTML 1.1 to "as implemented in modern browsers" is a great move to start with, at least

[13:30:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
anyway, vertical text support is extremely important for e-book-reading use cases in Japan

[13:30:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
I am told it is for Taiwan also

[13:30:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
though less so for mainland China

[13:31:00.0000] <Hixie>
yup

[13:31:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Apple's version of ePub will (as I'm sure has been previously mentioned) allow arbitrary HTML5 constructs

[13:31:02.0000] <othermaciej>
and people have in fact used it to embed video and audio and such in books

[13:31:03.0000] <othermaciej>
which is neat

[13:32:00.0000] <othermaciej>
from what I hear, there are a number of language features important for books in east asian locales

[13:32:01.0000] <othermaciej>
and people are pickier about some of them for books than for web sites

[13:32:02.0000] <othermaciej>
if Apple ends up doing any of them of course we'll feed the work into WebKit so it will be there for websites too

[13:33:00.0000] <othermaciej>
but I think most of the east asian language issues are mostly CSS level questions

[13:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
the only two vertical text things i'm aware of for html5 are to do with canvas drawText and captions

[13:34:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
othermaciej: yeah, I think for east-asian language/layout issues, it is mostly about CSS-level questions

[13:34:02.0000] <Hixie>

[13:34:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
othermaciej: and I will say that from what I see, people in Japan are definitely much pickier about language features for books than they are for websites

[13:35:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[13:35:01.0000] <Hixie>

[13:35:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[13:38:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[13:39:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
TabAtkins: I guess it's not reasonable to expect everybody in the group to see vertical text as a hugely higher priority

[13:40:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
maybe a lot of the work on driving it will end up coming from developers on the Chrome team in Japan

[13:40:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Well, we all want it.  The issue is *how*, because CSS in general contains a lot of assumptions that depend on horizontal text layout.

[13:40:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
ah

[13:40:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
I see

[13:40:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
There's the IE approach, frex, where switching the writing mode to vertical just "rotates" everything, so that, for example, padding-top now adds padding to one of the horizontal sides.

[13:41:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
But most people in the group think that's stupid.

[13:42:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
"frex" is an odd choice of a name for that

[13:42:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
frex = for example

[13:42:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
ah

[13:42:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
heh

[13:42:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
OK

[13:42:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'm inconsistent in my usage of that word.

[13:42:06.0000] <MikeSmith>
didn't grok the abbreviation at first

[13:42:07.0000] <TabAtkins>
I picked it up from some message board years ago and it's stuck in my head.

[13:43:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
just struck me in this case because in Japanese it's pronounced same as "flex"

[13:43:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Ah.

[13:43:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
no difference in translitering "r" and "l"

[13:44:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah.

[13:44:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
which is why I thought those freaking horn things were called "bubuzera"

[13:44:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
because that's what Japanese TV calls them

[13:44:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Hahaha.

[13:44:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
oh, no difference often between "b" and "v" too

[13:44:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
The correct term is "vulvazookeepers".

[13:45:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
heh

[13:45:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
So, back to technical talk.

[13:46:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Another possible solution is to introduce logical-direction equivalents of every physical-direction property, so you can do padding-before, frex, and have it mean padding-top in horizontal writing and padding-left or whatever in vertical writing.

[13:47:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
This would work "automatically", but only in relatively limited circumstances where you're not adjusting the layout based on writing mode.

[13:47:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
It also doesn't solve related problems, like the fact that in japanese vertical writing an underline goes on the opposite side of what you'd expect.

[13:48:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
So a third possibility is to have some sort of selector or media query or whatnot that distinguishes between when a document/element is in vertical or horizontal mode and lets you apply arbitrary CSS to it.

[14:06:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
TabAtkins: would seem like a good use for media queries

[14:07:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
There are complications, but yeah, probably.

[15:16:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
cool to see that abarth is starting work on the webkit html5 tree builder

[15:16:01.0000] <abarth>
MikeSmith: it's just a sketch at this point

[15:16:02.0000] <abarth>
MikeSmith: i'm trying a new control structure now

[15:16:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
I see

[15:16:04.0000] <abarth>
the problem is the way the spec is written is hard to implement directly

[15:17:00.0000] <abarth>
lots of "process blah as if foo"

[15:17:01.0000] <abarth>
also, as written, you need to make a ton of jump tables and branches for each character

[15:17:02.0000] <abarth>
which is really slow

[15:18:00.0000] <abarth>
instead of having the first branch be the insertion mode, i'm trying with the first branch being what token we're dealing with

[15:18:01.0000] <abarth>
which should push the character loop below all the jumping/branching

[15:20:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
interesting

[15:21:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
abarth: is that also in part because it'll make it easier for you to reuse the existing code?

[15:22:00.0000] <abarth>
MikeSmith: that design is closer to the way the old code works

[15:22:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
ok

[15:22:02.0000] <abarth>
the old code has a hash table keyed off the kind of token

[15:22:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
ah

[15:22:04.0000] <abarth>
and then a jump through a function pointer

[15:22:05.0000] <abarth>
to figure out what to do with the token

[17:56:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: I realize you are probably long ago bored with my mentioning the processing issues of the annotation-xml element 

[17:56:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
but I remembered something I didn't mention before

[17:57:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
the annotation-xml element has an "encoding" attribute

[17:57:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
which specifies a MIME type

[17:58:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
so if that is present and it specifies text/html, then seems like the parsing algorithm could use that info to do the similar behavior it does with SVG in there now

[17:58:01.0000] <Hixie>
that might make sense, yeah

[17:58:02.0000] <Hixie>
file a bug?

[17:58:03.0000] <MikeSmith>

[21:38:00.0000] <jmcneese>
howdy canvasers

[21:40:00.0000] <jmcneese>
so, can anyone answer if it is per spec/functionality that if i stroke a line in a canvas, it does not clear if if reset the canvas via changing the width or clearRect()?

[21:41:00.0000] <Hixie>
how do you mean?

[21:41:01.0000] <Hixie>
do you have a sample page showing the problem?

[21:41:02.0000] <jmcneese>
not on a reachable server.

[21:42:00.0000] <jmcneese>
it's simple to replicate.  start with an empty canvas.  draw a line down the center.  do a clearRect() on the canvas.  the line stays

[21:43:00.0000] <jmcneese>
curious if i'm missing a step

[21:45:00.0000] <Hixie>
what arguments are you passing clearRect()?

[21:48:00.0000] <jmcneese>
0,0,CANVASWIDTH,CANVASHEIGHT

[21:48:01.0000] <jmcneese>
it's working for any canvas i draw actual shapes on (rects, arcs, etc)

[21:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
so like:

[21:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
c.beginPath();

[21:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
c.moveTo(100,100);

[21:49:03.0000] <Hixie>
c.lineTo(200,300);

[21:49:04.0000] <Hixie>
c.stroke();

[21:49:05.0000] <Hixie>
c.clearRect(0, 0, 640, 480);

[21:49:06.0000] <Hixie>
...doesn't work?

[21:49:07.0000] <Hixie>
(where c is the context of course)

[21:50:00.0000] <jmcneese>
aha... is beginPath required?

[21:50:01.0000] <Hixie>
unless you do beginPath(), you're just adding to the last line each time

[21:50:02.0000] <Hixie>
stroke() doesn't reset the path

[21:51:00.0000] <jmcneese>
ok, noted.  but i don't see how that prevents the line from clearing when calling clearRect

[21:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. try:

[21:51:02.0000] <Hixie>
c.lineWidth=100; c.strokeStyle = 'red'; c.stroke();

[21:51:03.0000] <Hixie>
c.lineWidth=50; c.strokeStyle = 'orange'; c.stroke();

[21:51:04.0000] <Hixie>
c.lineWidth=10; c.strokeStyle = 'yellow'; c.stroke();

[21:52:00.0000] <Hixie>
well it's not that it prevents the line from being cleared, so much as you're probably calling stroke() again after you clear

[21:52:01.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. on a timer or something

[21:52:02.0000] <Hixie>
right?

[21:52:03.0000] <Hixie>
hard to say without seeing the code

[21:52:04.0000] <jmcneese>
i am calling redraw on mousedrag

[21:53:00.0000] <jmcneese>
now, since i couldn't get it to clear the lines for a grid, i ended up drawing rectangles (with three sides off canvas), which clear just fine

[21:54:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah the rect methods don't affect the path

[21:55:00.0000] <Hixie>
so they wouldn't get added each time

[21:55:01.0000] <Hixie>
the key is just that all the liens you add to the path don't get reset until you call beginPath() again

[21:55:02.0000] <jmcneese>
so, paths must be aha

[21:55:03.0000] <jmcneese>
that makes sense

[21:58:00.0000] <jmcneese>
thanks mate

[21:58:01.0000] <Hixie>
np

[01:44:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
"CSS syntax evolves in a backward- and forward-compatible way; the CSS 2.1 specification includes a uniform grammar, applicable to all CSS versions. The original (2002) W3C CSS Validator predates this uniform grammar and maintenance is becoming an undue burden as a result. This is an attempt to build a validator using the uniform syntax."

[01:44:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
hmm, so sounds like we are in pretty much the same situation with the CSS validator that we are with the current W3C Markup Validator

[01:45:00.0000] <boblet>
hrm, hopefully DanC gets some volunteers then eh

[01:45:01.0000] <boblet>
ok bbl, the little princess demands I play with her

[01:46:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
from what Dan says there, I can see that the existing CSS validator code, like the existing W3C Markup Validator code, is based on an obsolete backend, and we are not getting a good return on investment for the time we might put into maintaining it any further

[01:46:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
we just need to replace it

[01:46:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[16:49:00.0000] <aho>
var audio = new Audio();

[16:49:01.0000] <aho>

[16:52:00.0000] <taptapir>

[16:53:00.0000] <aho>

[16:59:00.0000] <roc>
you can create an anonymous audio element, give it anonymous <source> children, etc

[16:59:01.0000] <roc>
well not anonymous ,just not in the DOM

[16:59:02.0000] <roc>
note that "new Audio()" is equivalent to document.createElement("audio")


2010-06-28

[17:05:01.0000] <roc>

[21:47:00.0000] <nattokirai>

[21:48:00.0000] <nattokirai>

[21:48:01.0000] <roc>

[21:49:00.0000] <nattokirai>

[21:50:00.0000] <nattokirai>

[21:50:01.0000] <nattokirai>

I think we could get completely adequate book-reading typography in browsers with a combination of optimizations and CSS opt-in

[02:42:00.0000] <hsivonen>
roc: if raw perf is everything, why does Gecko do nice things for Latin text?

[02:42:01.0000] <roc>
on Windows and Linux, we actually don't

[02:43:00.0000] <hsivonen>
oh. :-(

[02:43:01.0000] <roc>
we have fast paths that bypass the shaper

[02:43:02.0000] <roc>
on Mac, well, we never got around to implementing the fast paths

[02:43:03.0000] <roc>
also the performance difference was never measured to be stunningly huge on Windows and Linux

[02:44:00.0000] <hsivonen>
roc: will the feature be available for opt-in once harfbuzz is used on all platforms?

[02:44:01.0000] <roc>
it's available for opt-in right now

[02:44:02.0000] <roc>
users can opt in via about:config, authors can opt in via text-rendering:optimizeLegibility

[02:44:03.0000] <roc>
(the latter also works on some Webkit ports, as I understand it)

[02:45:00.0000] <hsivonen>
nice.

[02:45:01.0000] <roc>
with Harfbuzz we're going to carefully measure the performance difference. Right now, Harfbuzz has no fast path

[02:45:02.0000] <hsivonen>
it sucks, though, that the default is optimizeBenchmarks

[02:45:03.0000] <roc>
it's not just benchmarks

[02:45:04.0000] <hsivonen>
what's the deal with camelCase in CSS?

[02:46:00.0000] <roc>
SVG screwed up

[02:46:01.0000] <hsivonen>
:-(

[02:46:02.0000] <roc>
Harfbuzz is considerably more optimizable of course, so I'm quite hopeful we can get away without any fast paths

[02:47:00.0000] <roc>
and we cache shaped text at the word level quite aggressively

[02:48:00.0000] <kling>
roc: harfbuzz performance is on the ToDo whiteboard behind me :]

[02:48:01.0000] <roc>
also, with Harfbuzz we can move most text shaping off the main thread if it's still showing up in profiles

[02:48:02.0000] <roc>

[08:33:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[08:34:01.0000] <kennyluck>
hahhah

[08:42:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Philip`: that's one of the many little-known features of RDF

[08:43:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
which is, there's a rule that when the string "RDF" precedes another three-letter string, the first two letters of the second string must then be transposed

[08:43:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
a lot of people think RDF is complicated, but I think that's a good example of a case where the rule is pretty simple

[08:44:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

2010-06-29
[18:31:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
I'm wondering what will happen to XHTML5 in strict mode. My previous attempts to use XHTML1 resulted in two problems.

[18:32:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
Problem #1: Due to a rather extreme interpretation of Postel's law in early browser designs, most developers don't even know what constitutes valid markup and how to escape content. Juniors on the team were clued out when it came to ampersands

[18:33:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
Problem #2: External libraries and other "foreign" code (e.g. https seals, ads, etc) always assume you're in text/html and use document.write()

[18:33:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
this blows up in Firefox

[18:33:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes?

[18:33:03.0000] <j0hng4lt>
(when served as application/xhtml+xml)

[18:34:00.0000] <webben>
j0hng4lt: I don't see how the new spec can make a dent in either problem.

[18:34:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
me neither...

[18:34:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
XML is always going to be strict, and suffer from the problems you've mentioned.  That's why XML isn't very useful for the web.

[18:34:03.0000] <j0hng4lt>
What I'm afraid of is that everyone will start "switching back to tag soup".

[18:34:04.0000] <webben>
j0hng4lt: But does it matter? Do you need XML for anything?

[18:35:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
The problem is not with XML... No one suffers from, say, a C# compiler not accepting invalid C#. Even VB programmers know how to close their while loops

[18:35:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
It's purely historical

[18:36:00.0000] <webben>
j0hng4lt: Ah but there's a big difference between closely controlled syntaxes (e.g. python) and loose syntaxes (e.g. perl, php)

[18:36:01.0000] <webben>
j0hng4lt: defined tag soup parsing is pretty much a loose syntax for the web.

[18:36:02.0000] <j0hng4lt>
I'm just afraid that everyone will start switching back to tag soup and start generating even more libraries that rely on Postel's Law Version 2 (be liberal in what you produce and in what you accept)

[18:37:00.0000] <webben>
j0hng4lt: And the "solution" for development teams seeking to regulate that syntax is the same as for such languages - use a linter.

[18:37:01.0000] <webben>
j0hng4lt: So long as the output is defined - does it matter? (Anymore than the looseness of Perl and PHP matter?)

[18:38:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
j0hng4lt: C# compilers can afford to reject invalid C#, because the programmer is guaranteed to see the failure before the user does.  On the web, the opposite is usually the case - users usually suffer from an XML failure before an author sees it.

[18:38:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
In simple terms, the user is the one holding the compiler on the web, and the author just ships source code.  This is obviously completely different from regular applications.

[18:39:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
Well... it's a bit of a "chicken-or-the-egg" question... Had the syntax been strict from the start, the authors would see the errors before the users did. The tools would have been different.

[18:39:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
But we are where we are...

[18:40:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
No, that doesn't fix anything at all.  People who know what they're doing and are *trying* to produce valid XML fail *all the time*.

[18:40:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
and it is impractical / infeasible to convert everything to strict syntax

[18:40:02.0000] <webben>
j0hng4lt: "the authors would see the errors before the users did". Not necessarily. HTML isn't a programming language - it's often (typically) /generated/ by code.

[18:40:03.0000] <j0hng4lt>
it's not that hard to produce valid xml if it's done by means other than string concatenation

[18:40:04.0000] <webben>
So there's no error for the programmer to see.

[18:41:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
(templates, linq-to-xml, XmlWriter, etc.)

[18:41:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
j0hng4lt: Yes, it is.  And still, nearly all programmers use string concatenation.

[18:41:02.0000] <j0hng4lt>
and in environments that escape by default

[18:42:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Virtually every framework ever invented uses string concat, and those that do try to do some escaping of the data often still miss things (like forgetting to remove U+0000 from input before shoving it into an element, which'll crash strict XML).

[18:43:00.0000] <webben>
e.g. the php dom implementation happily outputs characters that can't be legally placed in xml documents.

[18:45:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
again, this is a chicken-or-the-egg question... Most people who want to output valid XHTML fail - either because they can easily get away with it or because the tools mess it up for them...

[18:45:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
They don't normally fail to output valid XML

[18:45:02.0000] <j0hng4lt>
(e.g. valid RSS, valid sitemaps, etc.)

[18:45:03.0000] <j0hng4lt>
non-HTML applications of xml

[18:45:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
By "most" you mean "almost every single person on the web, given sufficient time or attackers".

[18:45:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
RSS is quite often invalid.

[18:47:00.0000] <webben>
locus classicus: http://www.xml.com/lpt/a/1450

[18:50:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Note as well:  "tag soup" is bad because everyone interpreted it differently, so you could never be sure what pops out.  HTML5, on the other hand, defines with absolute precision how to produce an HTML document from any random bag of bytes you throw at it.  As long as everyone follows the HTML5 parsing algorithm, you can know with absolute precision how your document will be interpreted.

[18:50:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
In my opinion, loose handling of semantics (e.g. a new element) is fine and dandy... What tends to get frustrating is loose handling of basic syntax... If something does break because of bad nesting (e.g. <form><table><tr><td>...</tr></td></form></table> - and most of the page looks like this) - you can't easily find the error because the validator will show an error on every line...

[18:51:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
I don't object to tag soup being handled given the situation

[18:51:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
I would have objected to it in the early 90s

[18:51:02.0000] <j0hng4lt>
but now you have to handle it whether you like it or not

[18:51:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
It would have failed back then as well, for the same reasons it fails today for people who are actually trying to produce valid XML.

[18:52:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
In environments that actually use xml parsers, failing to produce valid xml isn't that common

[18:53:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
My anecdotes contradict your assertion.

[18:53:01.0000] <webben>
in fairness, it would be easy to make a "strict" markup syntax that's simpler to produce than xml

[18:53:02.0000] <j0hng4lt>
And Postel's law was meant for forward and backward compatibility - not for the handling of badly written code

[18:53:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
In carefully controlled environments that aren't doing anything complicated, sure, valid XML might get produced by accident.

[18:56:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
Most applications of XML don't use string concat... They might generate semantic errors (e.g. throwing in an element that's not in the schema), sometimes by design, but you won't see nesting errors, naked ampersands, etc (i.e. well-formedness errors)

[18:57:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Actually, a significant number of XML-producing applications do produce wellformedness errors.  Usually they get nesting right, but they'll often happily output characters that aren't allowed unescaped in XML.

[18:57:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
Standard xml processing libraries in .net, java, and even in php are pretty good at well-formedness

[18:57:02.0000] <j0hng4lt>
the same goes for other strict formats

[18:57:03.0000] <j0hng4lt>
(json, .ini files, Apache config files)

[18:58:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
JSON is strict but also *very simple*, and has a single valid encoding.  It's trivial to produce valid JSON, unlike XML.

[18:59:00.0000] <Hixie_>
i dunno about _that_

[18:59:01.0000] <Hixie_>
it's simpler, sure, but not trivial

[18:59:02.0000] <othermaciej>
JSON has some quirky details

[18:59:03.0000] <othermaciej>
but indeed, it is much simpler than XML

[19:00:00.0000] <Hixie_>
JSON also still lacks error handling rules

[19:00:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
oh well... I've been seeing a lot of flame wars on the Interwebs along the lines of "xml sucks because it's complicated" or "xml sucks because it's sucks because it's xml"... In my opinion, XML is good for some tasks, bad for others. And generating any language using string concat is error-prone without a liberal parser

[19:00:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Hixie_: Right, JSON doesn't define what invalid JSON means.  It's "strict", in that invalid stuff just isn't JSON at all.

[19:00:03.0000] <j0hng4lt>
The main reason for the backlash against XML is its marketing... It was marketed as a panacea for everything

[19:01:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
But how can you get any simpler than the diagram at JSON.org?

[19:01:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
.ini files are simpler than json - but also more limited

[19:01:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
True.  But JSON isn't more limited than XML, so that comparison doesn't seem relevant.

[19:02:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
fixed-width records are still simpler than ini files

[19:03:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
The popularity of JSON is explained by the fact that it's easy to use in JavaScript.

[19:03:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
and very few people construct it manually

[19:04:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
most of the time, it is produced by a tool that cannot possibly generate invalid JSON

[19:04:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
e.g.

[19:04:02.0000] <j0hng4lt>
asp.net mvc: return Json(myObject);

[19:04:03.0000] <j0hng4lt>
php: echo json_encode($array);

[19:05:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
Constructing JSON with string concatenation would result in the same road blocks

[19:05:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
(e.g. having to escape quotes within strings)

[19:06:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
Also, JSON is more limited than xml. It lacks namespaces.

[19:07:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
But in the environment where it's normally used (AJAX calls), this limitation is irrelevant

[19:07:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
No it doesn't.  It lacks XML Namespaces.  That's not a weakness either.

[19:10:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
Without the tooling (XPath, XSLT, namespaces, schemas, etc.), it's a bare-bones format that does the same thing as XML (i.e. it's a text representation of a tree structure). If you reconstruct the tooling, it will have the same strengths and weaknesses as XML except for this:

[19:10:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
It will somewhat more succint (less space/bandwidth per payload if it is not compressed)

[19:11:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
And it will be slightly less readable / editable

[19:11:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I think most people find JSON much easier to read and edit than XML (me included).

[19:12:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
in notepad, yes... In an IDE with syntax completion... not really...

[19:12:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
But other than that, it reminds me of some of those good old flame wars

[19:12:02.0000] <j0hng4lt>
vi versus emacs

[19:12:03.0000] <j0hng4lt>
bash verus csh

[19:12:04.0000] <j0hng4lt>
*versus

[19:12:05.0000] <j0hng4lt>
tabs versus spaces

[19:13:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The difference being that the web has shown pretty conclusively that XML is not the right solution for webpages, unlike your choice of editor, shell, or indentation character.

[19:15:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
I think the reasons for that are purely historical...

[19:16:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Most people appear to disagree, and have expressed their reasoning in multiple blog posts and articles across the web.

[19:16:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
it tends to go back and forth...

[19:17:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
I think the biggest problem with standards in general

[19:17:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
(not just strict versus loose syntax)

[19:17:02.0000] <j0hng4lt>
is that on the web, standardization was a bit of an afterthought

[19:17:03.0000] <j0hng4lt>
(like with sql)

[19:18:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
most of the folks who actually develop web pages know anything beyond what gets displayed in the browser and what doesn't

[19:19:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
But I don't see why incorrect syntax couldn't be handled further upstream

[19:19:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
(e.g. by development tools)

[19:19:02.0000] <j0hng4lt>
but theory has to deal with reality...

[19:20:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
we have to deal with tag-soup parsing because we have a ton of tag soup... and wishing it disappeared wouldn't make it go away.

[19:20:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
What could've handled it back in the day is a strict-mode switch that gets ignored by old browsers and is honored by newer ones

[19:21:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
e.g. X-Parse-Mode=xml

[19:22:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
the switch that was chosen would break everything in IE

[19:22:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
so everyone would serve it as text/html

[19:23:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
since most people used ie anyway

[19:24:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
many third-party tools would continue with document.write(), direct output of html to stdout (<a href="<?=$foo->getLink() ?>">...</a> resulting in <a href="<b>Error:</b> File not found>...</a>)

[19:24:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
this made strict mode next to impossible

[19:26:00.0000] <roc>
awww I was just about to comment

[19:27:00.0000] <roc>
I will anyway

[19:27:01.0000] <roc>
Postel's world was a world where most people producing wire data knew what the standard was and were trying to hit it

[19:28:00.0000] <roc>
the world of Web standards is one where most producers of wire data have know little about the standards, don't care, and largely wouldn't be able to get it right if they did

[19:29:00.0000] <roc>
optimal behaviour in these two worlds is completely different

[19:29:01.0000] <roc>
</end>

[19:32:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
roc: don't try to cloud the discussion with irrelevant details about the realities of the environment

[19:34:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
In my opinion, the phenomenon that is the World Wide Web defies the logic of development / software engineering... It's a huge mess, and I find it rather surprising that it works at all...

[19:34:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
But the job of the Web developer has consisted of pushing square pegs through round holes from day 1

[19:35:00.0000] <roc>
ha

[19:35:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
(remember spacer gifs, two-layered tables to create a one-pixel border, javascript branching, etc...

[19:35:02.0000] <j0hng4lt>
)

[19:35:03.0000] <j0hng4lt>

[19:35:04.0000] <fecalpatties>

[19:36:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
The installation base and the heterogeniety of the systems involved is unprecedented.

[19:37:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
The most common anti-pattern found on the Web is Abstraction Inversion

[19:37:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstraction_inversion

[19:37:02.0000] <j0hng4lt>
Here are a few examples:

[19:37:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
j0hng4lt: I think you mean Inversion Abstraction

[19:37:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
(common mistake)

[19:38:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
Well... I learned the mistake from Wikipedia ;)

[19:38:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
here are a few examples:

[19:38:02.0000] <j0hng4lt>
- Using DIVs to render pixels in plotting libraries

[19:39:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
- Using a hidden iframe to communicate with the server from a client-side script

[19:39:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
j0hng4lt: Wikipedia is yet another example of Inversion Abstraction

[19:39:02.0000] <j0hng4lt>
(before the invention of ajax)

[19:40:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
- using background positioning to load multiple images at once

[19:41:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
Another big challenge on the Web is the fuzzy border between users and programmers

[19:44:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
(hence the reverse engineering of malformed code)

[19:47:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
indeed, hence

[19:48:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[19:50:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[19:52:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>

[19:53:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
Some people have pointed out that many programmers have failed to produce valid (XHTML|XML|HTML5|SGML|insert your language here).

[19:53:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>

[19:58:02.0000] <j0hng4lt>
Why can C# programmers produce valid C#? Actually, they can't. The compiler cactches the errors for them... And Visual Studio catches most errors before they even hit Compile.

[19:59:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
that's an interesting theory too

[20:01:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
One of the reasons why most of the mark-up on the Web is syntactically invalid, whereas most C# code is valid (despite HTML and XHTML constructs being far simpler than C#) is that the mark-up goes to the browser before anyone or anything sees it, and nothing sees it until it's FUBAR (i.e. until it's so messed up that the HTML parser would need an Artificial Neural Network to figure it out).

[20:02:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>

[20:21:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
REST is another interesting phenomenon... I do understand the initial arguments (i.e. using a GET request when you're not modifying stuff), but in a way, it's another case of going "back to the 90s"

[20:22:00.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: we plan to look at it, and also the associated charter for the potential WG around this

[20:24:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
i.e. In practice, you end up having to simplify / flatten the data structures you send to the service (i.e. you go from XML-serialized objects to key/value pairs), and the response could be just about anything as well - xml, json or even key-value pairs...

[20:24:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
I remember coding Web services before they were called Web services

[20:25:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
That was exactly what you would end up doing... You would send a GET or a POSt with URL-encoded key/value pairs and you would get the same thing back

[20:25:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
nothing wrong with the 90s

[20:25:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[20:25:03.0000] <MikeSmith>

[20:26:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
"The World Wide Web: The 00 Years"

[20:26:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
in terms of standards at least, not the best years

[20:27:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
My biggest frustration with the Web has been that, unlike with desktop development, you never get adequate tooling... The moment tools get built up, either they get obsolete or the Web goes up in arms with torches and pitchforks, calling for simplification

[20:27:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
then you get a conspiracy between Mort and Einstein to drive out Elvis

[20:28:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
So in the end, you're always coding in notepad (or do the equivalent thereof)... 

[20:29:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
The worst thing of the 00 years had to do with standards designed by committee

[20:29:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
that never got implemented

[20:29:02.0000] <j0hng4lt>
(e.g. XHTML2, CSS2, the beginnings of CSS3)

[20:30:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
the positive part of the OOs was the drive for structure (stricter syntax, schemas, etc.)

[20:30:01.0000] <j0hng4lt>
+ no more if (ie) { doThis() } else if (netscape) { doThat() } else { goToHell() }

[20:35:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
But in a way, we're seeing the Revenge of Mort in full swing... Loose syntax, no data structures, more copy-and-paste development, less widget-building

[20:36:00.0000] <j0hng4lt>
Ideally, I would like to be in a situation where Mort and Elvis can use the same Web without competing for space...

[00:04:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
dbaron: I'm not sure I understand your latest public-html message correctly

[00:04:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
so let me give an example and ask if it's the same as what you have in mind

[00:05:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
/me trots out a recent hobbyhorse

[00:05:01.0000] <dbaron>
ok

[00:06:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
the example is related to parsing of MathML content

[00:07:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
if the parsing algorithm encounters a MathML <annotation-xml> element, it essentially expects the content of that to be either and <svg> element or more MathML content

[00:08:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
but if the byte stream it parsing instead has HTML content in there, it goes back and pops elements off the stack until it encounters either a <math> or <svg> element

[00:09:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
the end

[00:11:00.0000] <hsivonen>
dbaron: I believe it is implied that there must be no other data structures hiding in the DOM tree than a Level 2 DOM and the references from form controls to forms

[00:11:01.0000] <hsivonen>
dbaron: but it's possible that it's not actually stated anywhere

[00:12:00.0000] <hsivonen>
it probably should be stated to make it clear that the kind of hidden data Opera and IE have is non-conforming

[00:13:00.0000] <hsivonen>
oh, and there are also the HTMLness flag and the quirkiness enum

[00:14:00.0000] <dbaron>
"No other data structures" might be too strong; it might make more sense to limit certain classes of behavior to not depending on other data structures

[00:15:00.0000] <dbaron>
in any case, I looked for a bit, and couldn't find any such requirements

[00:15:01.0000] <dbaron>
MikeSmith, I don't see how your example is related to what I was saying, although I could be missing something

[00:22:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
dbaron: no, I don't think you're missing anything -- after re-reading I see that you're referring to something other that what I meant by that example

[00:22:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
the "differences that must not matter" part in your subject line should have clued me in

[00:30:00.0000] <othermaciej>
good evening folks

[00:31:00.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen, dbaron: I think it would be a valid statement of fact that no conformance requirements in the spec would depend on the input document in any way other than as it affects the DOM

[00:31:01.0000] <othermaciej>
but I do not believe there is a requirement that browsers may not invent their own such behaviors

[00:31:02.0000] <othermaciej>
(so long as those behaviors are consistent with the existing UA conformance requirements)

[00:31:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I think it would be hard to scope it appropriately

[00:32:00.0000] <othermaciej>
for example, it's clear to me that a syntax-highlighted source view should be able to depend on the exact text input

[00:32:01.0000] <othermaciej>
or XHR.responseText

[00:39:00.0000] <dbaron>
but could one say, for example, that anything that depends on the element type (other than a display of the tag name) must not depend on things other than X?

[00:51:00.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: source view isn't really part of the interoperable platform

[00:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it's hard to construct conformance criterion that's a universal negative

[00:54:00.0000] <othermaciej>
maybe it would be preferable to just cite specific things that MUST NOT be affected by anything in the source document besides the output of the parsing algorithm

[01:08:00.0000] <MikeSmithX>
dbaron: btw, I wanted to ask if you might be planning an updates to the CSS3 syntax spec

[01:09:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
in particular, to the grammar and tokenizer parts

[01:09:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
I ask because Dan Connolly recently wrote a new CSS Validator (in Scala)

[01:10:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
with is designed to take a CSS grammar as an input

[01:10:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/css-val/raw-file/f5931981d7dd/README.html

[01:11:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
" the CSS 2.1 specification includes a uniform grammar, applicable to all CSS versions. The original (2002) W3C CSS Validator predates this uniform grammar and maintenance is becoming an undue burden as a result. This is an attempt to build a validator using the uniform syntax."

[01:11:01.0000] <dbaron>
I'm not planning an update; it's currently basically unowned.

[01:12:00.0000] <dbaron>
somebody writing a validator might make a good owner, though :-)

[01:12:01.0000] <dbaron>
anyway, g'night

[07:23:00.0000] <kennyluck>
By the way, Sean Palmer post gives us a hint on a use case of Semantic Web/RDF - decentralized issue tracking systems, so that we can make sure what we are working on (an issue) has a purpose (an issue that blocks this issue).

[07:24:00.0000] <kennyluck>
The reason why we need "decentralization" is the following use case. MikeSmith might want to create an issue "(super master bug) HTML5 implematations".

[07:24:01.0000] <kennyluck>
And this is blocked by the Mozilla HTML5 implemenation master bug and Webkit HTML5 implementation master bug.

[07:26:00.0000] <kennyluck>
As long as the Mozilla/Webkit HTML5 implementaion bugs are closed. We can close the "HTML5 implemetations" bug and release the W3C CR (correct me if I am wrong)

[07:26:01.0000] <Philip`>
He can do that without any RDF or semanticity, just by adding himself to the CC list on the Mozilla and WebKit bugzillas and noticing updates

[07:28:00.0000] <kennyluck>
Well, what I suggested was the feature -> "Allow an issue in a issue tracking system to block other issue in another domain". RDF is not required, indeed.

[07:28:01.0000] <kennyluck>
Any format that allows Linking *externally* is good enough. Microdata could be a choice.

[07:31:00.0000] <kennyluck>

[08:47:01.0000] <davidc>

[09:04:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
davidc: about the spec and HTML content within MathML content: the current handling is such that a conformant parser does what I described in my message, except within token elements

[09:05:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
that is, it basically ends up moving the HTML content out of document order to follow the mathml content

[09:05:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
so it does not do that only for the annotation-xml case

[09:10:05.0000] <MikeSmith>

[09:11:00.0000] <zcorpan_>

[09:11:01.0000] <davidc>
MikeSmith: yes but as I said somewhere if the mathml output from editors and CA systems etc is anotated then saying you can't use annotations in html means the editors have to change or users have to strip out the content or both

[09:11:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
jgraham: mathml within annotation-xml needs to be parsed as mathml, while html within mathml would need to be parsed as html

[09:12:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
davidc: well, somebody has to deal with costs here

[09:12:01.0000] <jgraham>
MikeSmith: Why? I thought it was fine to just ignore anything in annotation-xml?

[09:13:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
browser projects should not be expected to incur costs of implementing something with additional complexity unless the use cases for it are clear

[09:13:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
jgraham: it is display:none by *default*

[09:14:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
but what if an author sets its display property to something other than "none"?

[09:14:01.0000] <jgraham>
MikeSmith: It seems like we could just change the rules to put everything in annotation-xml in the html namespace. What use case requires something else?

[09:14:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[09:14:03.0000] <MikeSmith>

[09:14:04.0000] <jgraham>

[09:14:05.0000] <jgraham>

[09:15:00.0000] <davidc>

[09:15:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[09:15:02.0000] <zcorpan_>

[09:15:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
jgraham: we are trying to determine what the use cases are

[09:16:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
davidc: it is not the simplest of options, due to the fact that the spec chooses to allow both mathml and non-mathml content in annotation-xml

[09:16:01.0000] <jgraham>

[09:17:00.0000] <jgraham>

[09:17:01.0000] <jgraham>
/me guesses he should read the spec

[09:17:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
davidc: the reasons is because the parsing algorithm necessarily must handle HTML content within MathML in the way I've described

[09:17:03.0000] <davidc>
MikeSmith: well it was written for a simpler universe where every language used the same parsing model to avoid these problems.

[09:17:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
davidc: except for the special case of the token elements

[09:18:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
davidc: that is not the world we seem to find ourselves in

[09:18:01.0000] <davidc>
MikeSmith: oh? :-)

[09:18:02.0000] <jgraham>
zcorpan_: I think I would like to pretend that content mathml doesn't exist for the purpose of the web

[09:19:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
jgraham: it is not possible if you limit yourself to the standard/default MathML schema

[09:19:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
the standard schema only allows other namespaced content in annotation-xml

[09:19:02.0000] <jgraham>
Hmm

[09:19:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
that is why Jacques did it that way

[09:19:04.0000] <jgraham>
This seems like a lot of trouble

[09:20:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
but HTML5 parser allows it in the mathml "token elements" -- mi, mn, mn, mo, mtext

[09:20:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
so if Jacques were to use HTML5, he could/should just put it in mtext

[09:20:02.0000] <davidc>
jgraham: It's no trouble at all in the xhtml+mathml world for which it was designed, you can reliably parse past any content in annotation-xml, and by default you can always ignore it.

[09:20:03.0000] <jgraham>
I think I would prefer that approach in the long term

[09:20:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
what Jacques has in his examples is not even valid

[09:21:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Jacques examples have <semantics><annotation-xml> (annotation-xml element as 1st child of semantics, which is not valid)

[09:22:00.0000] <davidc>
MikeSmith: if the use case is to make the svg appear in the math, putting in a token element rather than the annotation makes perfect sense

[09:22:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
Jacques it just relying there on some rendering behavior that just happens to work in Firefox but that is not really conformant to the MathML spec

[09:23:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
davidc: that is exactly what Jacques is using it for

[09:23:01.0000] <davidc>
If annotation-xml is proving difficult in text/html then just parsing it and leaving it in the dom unrendered would do, or if that's not possible, even just throwing the content away would do.

[09:23:02.0000] <jgraham>
MikeSmith: Based on what davidc is saying it seems like we really don't want to make annotation-xml insanely complex because it is mostly just for tool-specific junk that is not relevant to end users

[09:23:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
it is exactly what every page I have seen on the Web is using <annotation-xml> for

[09:23:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
davidc: understood

[09:23:05.0000] <davidc>
Yes but like the rest of us he tries to tread a line between what's specified and what works. He would change if what was specified also worked.

[09:25:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[09:25:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
but zcorpan_ pooh-poohed that for some reason

[09:25:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[09:26:00.0000] <davidc>
jgraham: well it might be relevant to end users, but it isn't relevant to the browser except for just being a data format. If I cut and paste an expression out of the browser, it would be nice (and works by the way in IE) if the annotations went along with it, then if I paste into say (maple0 it may well be able to evaluate the content mathml, even if teh presentation mathml is showing some...

[09:26:01.0000] <davidc>
...strange notation only used in one textbook

[09:26:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
e.g, in order to have some annotation-xml content parsed as HTML, you'd need to do annotation-xml/@encoding=text/html

[09:26:03.0000] <zcorpan_>
MikeSmith: because it complicates the parser and we've generally tried to avoid inspecting attributes in the parser

[09:27:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
zcorpan_: OK

[09:27:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
ah yeah

[09:27:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
that makes sense, yeah

[09:28:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
davidc: what zcorpan_ said .. inspecting the values of particular attributes during DOM tree-building is something to be avoided

[09:28:01.0000] <davidc>
MikeSmith: agreed

[09:30:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
davidc: stepping back, let me make clear: as currently specced, everything essentially works as users might expect -- with the one exception of the case of HTML content in annotation-xml

[09:31:00.0000] <davidc>
All I really care about is that the parser 9using whatever parsing model is convenient for you to specify) gets as far as </annotation-xml> and then carries on the rendering as if it wasn't there. It would be nice if it stuffed the annotation somewhere usable by script but that isn't absolutely essential.

[09:31:01.0000] <davidc>
MikeSmith (how do you folks keep up with teh bandwidth on irc conversations:-) perhaps that is not as bad as it originally seemed

[09:32:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
davidc: so it will essentially to that for everything except HTML in annotation-xml

[11:53:01.0000] <Philip`>

[11:53:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[11:53:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, yes, but that's not the constraint we're discussing here.

[11:54:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[11:54:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
That would be entirely realistic, since fuel is likely to be a serious limiting factor even for advanced spacecraft.

[11:54:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Depending on how fast you want to travel.

[11:54:03.0000] <Philip`>
Perhaps you could say the spaceship has very limited fuel(/energy) storage (to save mass) and so it has to generate energy as it's required, and it can use that energy for either acceleration or shielding against micrometeorites

[11:54:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
In any case, I'm talking game-fun.  If you go fast enough, you literally hover off the edge of the screen.

[11:55:00.0000] <Philip`>
and you're in a region of space where there's a lot of very slow-moving micrometeorites

[11:55:01.0000] <Philip`>
so if you're stationary relative to them, then you don't need much shielding and can accelerate fast

[11:55:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
You're just reintroducing drag with more technobabble.

[11:55:03.0000] <Philip`>
but as you move faster you have to slow down acceleration, until you reach a top speed where all your energy is shielding you from collisions

[11:55:04.0000] <TabAtkins>

[11:56:00.0000] <Philip`>
It's not drag since you're not transferring momentum to your surroundings

[11:56:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
The effect is the same - as you go faster, an outside force gradually saps more of your acceleration.

[11:57:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, your technobabble is fairly impressive.

[11:57:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[11:57:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[11:57:03.0000] <Philip`>

[11:58:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[11:58:01.0000] <Philip`>

[11:59:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: The shields are magnetically-contained plasma envelope that vaporize micrometeorites before they touch the hull.

[11:59:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, then your target could decelerate it.  They'd be able to spot you accelerating such a large object that much from billions of miles away.

[12:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
AryehGregor: The 'shields' are just lasers that vapourise micrometeorites, so that the collision energy is dispersed and easily handled by the hull

[12:00:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, if they're magnetically contained, why do you need any energy input?  Also, vaporizing them doesn't get rid of the kinetic energy.

[12:00:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: You start the acceleration out pretty far, preferably off the ecliptic as well so it's harder to notice.

[12:00:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, okay, I'm beginning to buy this.

[12:01:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, the further away you accelerate it from, the longer it takes to get there.  Unless you accelerate it more, but then that cancels out the greater distance, so it doesn't help you.

[12:01:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: Electromagnets.  Also, vaporizing them allows the plasma to absorb their momentum, thus spreading the impact over the entire magnetic field rather than focused on a point.

[12:01:02.0000] <Philip`>
AryehGregor: You find a rock that's going to go close to the sun, secretly attach some rockets to it, then activate them when it's got close so the light from the sun masks the rocket activity

[12:01:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: The point is that the further you start it out, the bigger head start you have.

[12:01:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Electromagnets don't consume energy to stay on, if you're smart and use a superconductor.

[12:02:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, but it will be clearly visible from a different angle.

[12:02:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: These people aren't smart enough to realize that the ether isn't real, you think they'd use a superconductor?

[12:02:02.0000] <Philip`>
or you just stick a giant screen around the rock before you boost it so that nobody sees

[12:02:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[12:02:04.0000] <AryehGregor>

[16:45:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Murata-san is 1998 - http://lists.xml.org/archives/xml-dev/199808/msg00164.html

[16:46:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
[[

[16:46:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
As a member of the WG, I have been involved.  I have agreed on colonization, 

[16:46:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
and have always believed that colonization provides a good basis for 

[16:46:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
the namespace extension.  Now that we have local scoping and declaration by 

[16:46:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
attributes, I start to wonder.

[16:46:05.0000] <MikeSmith>
Since the same prefix can be bound to 

[16:46:06.0000] <MikeSmith>
different namespaces, it is no longer possible to construct an equivalent 

[16:46:07.0000] <MikeSmith>
XML 1.0 DTD from a collection of namespace-schema pairs.  Then, what is 

[16:46:08.0000] <MikeSmith>
the point of using prefixes?

[16:46:09.0000] <MikeSmith>
 It would have 

[16:46:10.0000] <MikeSmith>
been a lot simpler if we had introduced a reserved attribute for specifying 

[16:46:11.0000] <MikeSmith>
the namespace of the element.

[16:46:12.0000] <MikeSmith>
]]

[16:46:13.0000] <Hixie>
man that would have been hella verbose

[16:47:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
<svg namespace="foobar">?

[16:47:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah, sure

[16:47:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
more <svg xmlns="foobar> I guess

[16:48:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
oops

[16:48:01.0000] <Hixie>
if it was scoping that might work for svg, html, mathml, etc; wouldn't be very pretty for rdf

[16:49:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
Philip`: seems it was xml with sentence-for-sentence translations

[16:49:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
No, rdf would have sucked with that.

[16:49:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
But it feels like it would have been saner for normal elements.

[16:50:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I just point it out as a reminder that there was nothing close to real consensus in the WG at that time

[16:50:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
no consensus that prefix mechanism was the right way

[16:51:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
just as there was also no consensus then about draconian error handling being the right way

[16:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
just as there's no consensus in the htmlwg that html5 is the right way :-)

[16:51:02.0000] <Hixie>
consensus isn't a good language design mechanism

[16:53:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
well it's especially not a good design mechanism when claims are made that it exists for a particular issue when it really does not

[16:53:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
decision about draconian error handling was made by simple majority vote

[16:53:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
which is not consensus anyway

[17:25:00.0000] <variable>

[17:25:01.0000] <zcorpan_>

[17:25:02.0000] <variable>

[17:25:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
variable, no, it's radically different in lots of ways.

[17:25:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
However, it should be similar enough for most purposes.

[17:26:00.0000] <roc>
what Aryeh said

[17:26:01.0000] <variable>
AryehGregor, can you explain? I'm not /that/ knolegeable. 

[17:26:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, it's an iframe.

[17:26:03.0000] <variable>
*not that familier with how it works

[17:26:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
It integrates better than a regular iframe, but still an iframe.

[17:26:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
So there's a whole separate document inside.

[17:27:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
But you can make it blend in to the bigger document visually, etc.

[17:27:01.0000] <roc>
it's a separate document, it's in a rectangle

[17:27:02.0000] <variable>
AryehGregor, in a seamless iframe is top.location == location ?

[17:27:03.0000] <roc>
for example you can't expect to put inline content in it and wrap that content at line breaks

[17:27:04.0000] <roc>
it has its own DOM

[17:27:05.0000] <roc>
its top.location != location in general

[17:28:00.0000] <variable>
so what does "When specified, it indicates that the iframe  element's browsing context is to be rendered in a manner that makes it appear to be part of the containing document (seamlessly included in the parent document). "

[17:28:01.0000] <variable>
mean? or can you point me to some "newbie" docs the issue?

[17:29:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
It means that it should look like the <iframe> tag wasn't there at all.

[17:30:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
(Replaced by the contents of the contained document.)

[17:30:01.0000] <variable>
so to the enclosing page there is no iframe but to the iframe content it is on its own

[17:31:00.0000] <variable>
/me has to learn how to read the spec better

[17:31:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Visually, yes.  In all other respects, the <iframe> is still there and acts normally.

[17:31:02.0000] <variable>
Ah. I see. 

[17:31:03.0000] <variable>
There is no "client side include" but you can get the visual effect. OK

[17:32:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah.

[17:32:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Actualy client-side includes have to be faked with javascript and xhr.

[17:32:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
s/Actualy/Actual/

[17:32:03.0000] <variable>
ok. good to know

[02:19:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[02:20:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[02:20:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[02:21:00.0000] <hsivonen>
I think this leaves three options:

[02:21:01.0000] <hsivonen>
 1) Ignoring </html> (and maybe </body>) in 'in foreign content'

[02:21:02.0000] <hsivonen>
 2) popping all foreign stuff off the stack when transitioning to 'after body'

[02:22:00.0000] <hsivonen>
3) making an exception in the end tag handling in 'in foreign' so that the first item on the stack never gets popped no matter what

[02:40:00.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: eltPosForeign represents /node/ from the spec (by index)

[02:40:01.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: the three lines at http://hg.mozilla.org/projects/htmlparser/rev/b08b9993cd5d#l1.66 are one addition

[02:41:00.0000] <hsivonen>
fixing http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9580

[02:42:00.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: http://hg.mozilla.org/projects/htmlparser/rev/b08b9993cd5d#l1.64 fixes http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9582

[02:42:01.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: currentPtr is the index of the top aka. bottom of the stack

[02:44:00.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: it it is smaller than the just-decremented eltPosForeign, the secondary insertion mode has popped so much stuff that it would be bad to continue per spec before /node/ is in range for the current stack again

[02:45:00.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: the left-hand part of the |if| condition on line http://hg.mozilla.org/projects/htmlparser/rev/b08b9993cd5d#l1.57 fixes http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9581

[03:08:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[03:08:01.0000] <hsivonen>
normally, </dl> doesn't match a <dl> if there's a scoping element in between

[03:09:00.0000] <jgraham>
*scoping

[05:18:00.0000] <roc>

[05:18:01.0000] <roc>

[05:19:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[05:19:01.0000] <roc>

[05:20:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[05:21:00.0000] <roc>

[05:22:00.0000] <roc>

[05:23:00.0000] <roc>
it's because then I can have requestFullScreen(Element); cancelFullScreen() where cancelFullScreen takes no parameter

[05:23:01.0000] <roc>
so there's no confusion about what should happen if you do elem1.requestFullScreen(); elem2.cancelFullScreen();

[05:23:02.0000] <roc>
I suppose I can have cancelFullScreen on the Document only

[05:24:00.0000] <zcorpan_>

[10:07:00.0000] <Philip`>
TabAtkins: Why do you think there's a problem?

[10:08:00.0000] <Philip`>

[10:08:01.0000] <Philip`>
and the processing algorithm ignores that too

[10:09:00.0000] <Philip`>
(i.e. empty and/or XML-incompatible names aren't allowed but will be extracted by the algorithm)

[10:10:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Well, it doesn't gain us anything to process <div data-=foo>, since there isn't anything on the web that depends on it.  Might as well align author and impl requirements here.

[10:11:00.0000] <Philip`>
Do you want to align to the XML-compatible requirement too?

[10:14:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Maybe, though I'd be equally happy to drop that requirement.

[10:19:00.0000] <jgraham>
The empty string case is confusing

[10:19:01.0000] <jgraham>
So that shouldn't work, I think

[10:21:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
We're already verifying that the name doesn't include any capital letters, so I suspect it's not overly a burden to verify that it only contains characters in the xml-compatible range.

[10:21:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
(http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-xml/#NT-NameStartChar and NameChar)

[10:21:02.0000] <annevk>
that seems like overkill

[10:23:00.0000] <annevk>

[10:24:00.0000] <Philip`>

[13:03:00.0000] <Hixie>
zcorpan_: thanks for the notes on the wiki

[13:03:01.0000] <zcorpan_>
np

[13:25:00.0000] <Hixie>
zcorpan_: we can go several ways on the timestamp parsing thing

[13:25:01.0000] <Hixie>
zcorpan_: we could just support arbitrary values in each field, and then add them together without checking ranges

[13:26:00.0000] <Hixie>
zcorpan_: so e.g. 1:60:60,60000 would turn into 1 hour + 60 minutes + 60 seconds + 60000 thousandths, i.e. 2h2m, same as 02:02:00.000

[13:27:00.0000] <Hixie>
zcorpan_: we could check ranges, but support missing zero padding, so e.g. 1:1:1,1 => 01:01:01.001

[13:28:00.0000] <Hixie>
zcorpan_: or we could be strict, and not support this contentz

[13:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
zcorpan_: any opinions?

[13:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
i went with the first option

[13:35:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
that's what i was going to suggest (for compat with vlc and mplayer; i have no idea if there's any content that relies on this)

[13:37:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Adding them all together is the best.  Makes so many things simpler when you don't have to futz around with doing base-60 arithmetic yourself.

[13:37:01.0000] <Hixie>
well there's the content you pasted which relies on us doing either the first two and not the third

[13:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
TabAtkins: well they're still not valid at the moment

[13:38:01.0000] <Hixie>
this is just error handling behaviour

[13:38:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
d'oh.

[13:38:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
I like it when that sort of thing is expicitly allowed.

[13:38:04.0000] <Hixie>
we can talk about what should be valid too, but that's a discussion for another time

[13:38:05.0000] <Hixie>
i'm starting the format as strict as possible in terms of what's allowed, e.g. it even wants the cues in order

[13:38:06.0000] <Hixie>
which i imagine we'll later relax

[13:38:07.0000] <Hixie>
but we'll see

[13:39:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
/me thinks specifically of date libraries that are perfectly happy being asked to create a datetime for March -3 or whatever.

[15:43:00.0000] <roc>
WebSRT is renderable markup, EventSource and manifest are not

[15:43:01.0000] <roc>
the argument that "right now we only need a simple subset, so let's spec our own" is why SVG started encroaching on HTML and CSS

[15:44:00.0000] <roc>
it's troublesome because of course the requirements grow over time, and at each step the easiest thing to do for implementers, spec authors and Web authors is to add one more feature to the stand-alone subset

[15:45:00.0000] <roc>
however, argument by analogy is weak so that doesn't settle the issue
